They make that kind of money in less then a week. Does anybody anywhere really believe aapl will ever raise cash for anything with their 130 bil worth of cash equivalent? To put if bluntly: AAPL management work for their self glorification, their fun. With most of the options at top level exercised at top prices they don't care about the price anymore. Topic.Title: Lets Look at some facts.. And please only rational people respond .. Short or long .. But bashers please take a coffee brake

Message.Msg: Wow, finally someone will to discuss what is going on. Thank you, you've restored my faith in message boards. True, it certainly could be used for a purchase outside of the US. And even with paying the taxes it is a boat load of money, but being accurate is important. With the iPad mini being in full supply starting this quarter you are not only looking at pressure on the margin, but cannibalization of the full size iPad sales. Now factor in the iPhone5 has already launched in every country compared to last year, how are sales going to hold up not only next quarter, but the following two? If revenue growth is decelerating from close to 55% to 7% for the second quarter yoy how does that project for the following two quarters? Revenue should be close to flat and a slight decline wouldnt surprise me since as the iPhone5 ages sales will decrease. EPS will decrease and decrease more as a percentage than the 2nd qtr. I doubt there will be as much excitement for the iPhone6 as there was for the 5 so maybe people wont put off buying a phone in the 4th quarter, but that isnt exactly a reason to get excited. Obviously new products that really drove up sales might make the difference, but EPS, if you can believe Apple's guidance, is certainly going to drop to drop at least 10% in the second quarter. Looking at the compressed margins, declining revenue growth and factoring in the 3rd and 4th quarters are historically the weakest I'm pretty comfortable with predicting a 10-14% overall decrease in EPS. Apple needs a new product and/or a way to make money off the ecosystem like they do with apps and music. Absent that jack up the dividend to $15 a share @ 3% it might attract a new class of investors, but my guess is they go with 10-12% which will have no impact on the share price.

Topic.Title: Crammer just said that AAPL shareholders should expect more pain unless

Message.Msg: Cramer may be right. Value folks want to see at least 3% dividend yields inho. AAPL had various means to get to that minimum 3% yield. Mathematically, AAPL needs a .6% increase in yield from current 2.4%. If AAPL increases its quarterly dividend from 2.65 to 3.375 per share, that would do it by itself. Or, AAPL could let the market send the yield to 3% by going to $353 per share and maintaing status quo on current dividend policy. Rarely do companies increase their dividends by 27% on an ongoing basis.

Topic.Title: Please stop lying Appleheads

Message.Msg: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) -- Samsung Electronics Co. said quarterly profit soared 76 percent, boosted by the popularity of its Galaxy smartphones, which outsold the iPhone for a fourth straight quarter. But the company said Friday it expects earnings to decline during the current quarter because of seasonally low demand for consumer electronics. It is also leaving its 2013 capital expenditure at the same level as last year at 23 trillion won ($21.5 billion), underlining uncertainty about the global economy and declining demand for personal computers. The strong South Korean won is also becoming a negative for Samsung. It expects more than 3 trillion won will be shaved from its 2013 operating profit due to the stronger local currency. Samsung's shares fell as much as 3 percent after earnings release. Net profit for the final quarter of 2012 totaled 7.04 trillion won ($6.6 billion), a 76 percent surge from 4.01 trillion won a year earlier. Analysts had expected 6.95 trillion won in net profit, according to financial information provider FactSet. Sales rose 19 percent over a year earlier to 56.06 trillion won and operating income jumped 89 percent to 8.84 trillion won. Increased sales of smartphones were the key source of its profit growth. Samsung, which overtook Apple Inc. as the top smartphone maker last year, said its operating profit from the division that makes and sells smartphones and tablets more than doubled to 5.44 trillion won in the fourth quarter, from 2.56 trillion won a year earlier. Most analysts believe the Suwon, South Korea-based Samsung shipped more than 60 million smartphones, including the Galaxy S III and Galaxy Note II, during the three months ending in December, which would put the year's smartphone sales at more than 200 million. Apple said it sold 47.8 million iPhones in the quarter. Hong Kong-based research firm Counterpoint Research said Samsung took 33 percent market share in the fourth quarter, compared with Apple's 21 percent. Anot

Message.Title: Some thoughts about an Apple TV
Message.Msg: Assume Apple sells a TV. Let's put the size at 52 inches. Would it be sold in Apple stores. Highly unlikely. No one is walking out of the store with a 52 inch TV. Unlike Best Buy, HH Gregg many Apple stores are in congested big cities like Philadelphia, New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. You can actually walk out of the door at Best Buy with TV on a hand truck and bring it home if you have a large SUV. Apple doesn't have a delivery company that offers "White Glove" service. They would have to contract with one that would deliver the TV from their shipping warehouse and set up the TV in the buyers home. I bought a 65 inch Panasonic from a catalog gift company. They not only had to deliver the TV but they had to attach the stand and place it on my TV table. They also have to make sure the TV is operational and not DOA. Apple venturing into the TV business is a whole new ballgame. If you buy an iPhone, iMac, Macbook it is easy to go back to the Apple store and exchange the product if it is not working. All the products that Apple sells now offer instant gratification. What that means is I buy the product and can use it a few hours later. That is not the case of the TV which you have to schedule and wait for delivery. How do you display an Apple TV in an Apple Store. A 52 inch TV takes up a lot of space. Best Buy and many other stores display their TV's in a darkened part of the store. An Apple store is bright and white. You need to stand several feet away from the TV to see if you like it. The store is not set up for that with the aisles loaded with Apple products. Tim Cook and the people who work for Apple are really smart guys. I'm sure they have thought many of things out but as you can see saying you are going to design and sell a TV is a lot harder than actually doing it.

Topic.Title: Lets Look at some facts.. And please only rational people respond .. Short or long .. But bashers please take a coffee brake

Message.Msg: Great post, and many good responses. Thanks for sharing. I have been an Apple believer since the last decade. I thought the current quarter was pretty good... however, the margins softened up considerably. It doesn't take a genius to figure out: We made the same profits as last year, although we sold over $8 billion more of products. What's wrong or right with that picture? The earnings line hurt Apple big time. Wall Street would have been kind with revenue miss. But Street is always unkind with margins. Further, Apple projected a narrow revenue range of $41 to $43 billion for next quarter, which was less by more than $2.4 billion than the average analysts expectation. This has worried a lot of analysts. Not only Apple projected a lower revenue outlook for next quarter, but also they are projecting lower profits. Analysts must be thinking that Apple is hurting on both ends: Growing the company by more than 15% YOY, but also growing the EPS. They have been so used to the hyper growth years of Apple. This is a huge Reset. Another factor for margin compression is declining Mac sales by over 1 million. Macs produce the highest margins. How can a company sell so few Macs for the whole quarter? I know Tim Cook tried to explain this on the CC, but it still leaves a lot of unanswered questions. Apple just introduced the best MacBook line up in years with the Retina display. Why are they not selling? It's not just iMacs. One of the answers given was that the overall PC market has been very soft. But 4 million Macs sold is a huge miss in itself. Remember Apple missed on analyst earnings two quarters in a row. So, to right the ship, Apple has to come back with a bang this quarter. Show that they can deliver a big revenue number and most importantly, sizable earnings beat. Analysts are not convinced at this time. They would take a wait and see approach. As for buying, selling, shorting or holding - very hard to pick any of these four! Most of us who held have lost a ton!

Message.Title: AT&T Inc. T -0.09% said Thursday it activated 8.6 million iPhones in the fourth quarter, while selling a total of 10.2 million smartphones.
Message.Msg: AT&T Inc. T -0.09% said Thursday it activated 8.6 million iPhones in the fourth quarter, while selling a total of 10.2 million smartphones. The popularity of the iPhone at the No. 2 carrier echoed a report this week from market leader Verizon VZ -0.47% Wireless, which said about two-thirds of the 9.8 million smartphones it activated in the fourth quarter were Apple devices. Those results support recent surveys that show the iPhone remains the country's most popular smartphone. But Apple may have to do more to persuade shoppers to buy its priciest models.

Topic.Title: I need serious help... please help..... I'm truthfully speaking here so I please be kind.

Message.Msg: Coffeebook, you said you had enough excess in your account to weather a further drop. That being said, buy a couple of puts for 2/16 just like your calls. Purchase the puts around 430-450 depending on how much money you want to spend. That will protect you somewhat to the downside. Keep your 2/16 calls because it will rebound prior to 2./16, may not go 500 but could very well have a $40-50 up day and your calls will go back up in value, probably not to what you paid because there was a huge premium on those options prior to AAPL earnings. Never buy a high priced high flying stock like AAPL just before earnings because the options have a high premium built in, only do that unles you hedge it in the event the stock goes against your primary initiative. So buy you a couple of puts, if the stock drops further you will make money on the puts which will offset a further loss on your calls. Don't panic, the stock will have a huge up day, when the big investors decide to get back in it'll pop huge so hang in there. Hope this helps, good luck and God Bless!!! P.S. Like my alias says, don't watch CNBC whatever you do.....

Topic.Title: I need serious help... please help..... I'm truthfully speaking here so I please be kind.

Message.Msg: I think that, given today's price depression, a 50 dollar move to the upside is about the same chance as another 20 dollars of downside. We know that Apple isn't going bankrupt in the near future, and you can weather another 20 dollars of downside so my suggestion is as follows. Sell the calls that you have that are just plain options, those are just going to deteriorate with time. If apple doesn't bounce back in a day, assume it will take a while to come back to 500+, so on monday sell a call to cover your 100 shares. You are prob paying a hefty chunk of change for the margin interest on your shares, and this will offset that while the shares languish down. My suggestion is to go with a call with a strike price over 500. If you end up in the money, roll it forward a month. If the shares do end up assigned and you don't roll, at least you sold at 500 which is much better than today's 450. Good luck.

Topic.Title: Lets Look at some facts.. And please only rational people respond .. Short or long .. But bashers please take a coffee brake

Message.Msg: I believe that lack of imac sales for almost two months hurt that number.... Mind u.. Even the old imac was out of supply prior to the release of the new one. Then you have the supply constraints....which added to the issue. Then the decline in pc sales over all. And the cannibalization of macs through ipads. Topic.Title: I need serious help... please help..... I'm truthfully speaking here so I please be kind.

Message.Msg: I'm sorry about your troubles. I did post previously about there being a Head & Shoulders chart pattern. This is a bearish pattern. My target is set at 354 with good support at 350. There is an open gap at 420 which needs to be filled. Gaps are filled 95% of the time, and the market will not forget about this one. Thanks to Eliott Wave Theory, stocks zig zag. They do not go straight down or straight up. Because AAPL has gotten away from the moving averages, APPL must return to the means. In other words, it needs to meet up with the moving averages. AAPL will either move sideways to allow the moving averages to catch up, or it will turn back up to meet with them. If it moves sideways, there is a possibility prices will drop lower. If I were you, I would learn to trade with the trend. It will keep you out of trouble, and to avoid a falling knife. Here's a tip. Watch for a 13/34 EMA crossover. You can use it on any time frame. When the 13 is above 34, the stock is bullish. Play with it and let it be your best friend. Good luck to you. dj

Message.Title: Goldman slashes Apple price target by $100
Message.Msg: Apple Inc.'s AAPL -12.35% 12-month price target was cut to $660 from $760 a share on Friday by Goldman Sachs "Apple's guidance was essentially what we expected from the typically conservative management team. The problem, and the key disappointment in the call, was that management made it pretty clear that it was moving towards providing more realistic guidance." The iPhone product cycle hasn't been able to deliver the upside Apple investors are accustomed to, and post-holiday demand for the product also disappointed, the bank said. Goldman also cut its fiscal year 2013-2015 revenue estimates by 2% to 6% and earnings per share estimates by 6% to 14%, but kept Apple on its conviction-buy list, on "optimism that new products in the coming months will invigorate new user growth." Key risks include delayed product cycles, supply chain problems, product price erosion and a slower pace of product innovation, Goldman said. Key headline: $100 cut. Is that another way of saying "Sell"? And then they kept Apple on the Buy list. How strange?

Topic.Title: Why sudden price drop Jan 24th?

Message.Msg: guidance was a bit of a surprise, as he guided with upper bound of about 10.5 EPS. So Q2 trailing are going to be 42 EPS (since we loose two bucks). - Decelerating growth - Also he pretty much shot down the notion of making a bigger phone, which at least half of the potential customers who are able to afford a high end phone want. - Seems there is nothing else in the pipe than iPhone5 and 5S for the next two years. A TV would matter much in term of revenues. This seems incredible to me that they would want to continue going for the next two year with only one high end phone like iphone5. Seems that they are making the same mistake than the one Jobs made when he claimed that 7" tablets where DOA. - China mobile and cheap phone are just rumors at this point - Mac sales decelerating Also no moat. Apple is not like Google or amazon of FB, it has no moat that protect its core business. They won't stop making money but their major revenue source (iphone5) is not that credible. They can easily be displaced (Galaxy S3 and notes sold about 30M last quarter, so the threat is real). Anyhow, seems there is no clarity whatsoever and decelerating growth is now actually happening. Main source of revenue is at risk, not dead, but there is indeed a risk. Considering the staggering size of the market capitalization, a PE of 10 or 9 might be justified, who knows? To reach a PE of 10 with 40 or 42 EPS for 2013 you need 400$ I was a buy before and lost money, but not anymore. The conference call convinced me more than the actual earnings... Maybe the story will be nice, they'll produce a compelling iPhone5S and remain dominant in the high end market, then maybe they'll actually make a cheaper phone and sell hundred of millions of those at 20% margin, thus adding to their bottom line. But at this point this is all smoke, and as Tim hinted that this wont happen this year, so I wouldn't count on it... Or, Maybe they'll keep iPhone5 for two year and be decimated by samsung....

Message.Title: I Have 38 Years Of Stock Market Experience
Message.Msg: And every time this happens I promise myself I'll remember next time. The market cycle is driven by the 4 year presidential election cycle. On average we go up for 2.67 years and down for 1.33 year. This bull market is almost 4 years old. The election is over. Taxes are going up. Obamacare will raise most people's deductible in 2014. Apple's earnings were great, but confirmed that people are buying the lower priced iPhones (4's instead of 5's). What I learned in 1984, 2000 and 2008 is don't over stay a bull market. We now in a bear market and most people don't see it because unemployment is a lagging indicator. Eventually everything will go down. Preserve your capital. In the long run, you'll make a lot more money and lose a lot less sleep. LOL. i am writing this at 4 AM.. Apple is over owned and momentum will drive it down 50% from the top. 4 years from now Apple will hit $1000, but first its got to wash out a lot of middle class investors and buy back 50% of their shares. That's going to be hard to do with only $200B and that number is before taxes. Preserve your capital and go to church and talk to real people. That's what I relearned in 2008. Topic.Title: AAPL HAS NO GROUND TO STAND ON

Message.Msg: What I said was real and came from heart. Does it take someone more than 35 years of investing to convince others what may happen? The fact is in my post. Any investor must not jump into a company without studying the company financially and technically. AAPL now is closing to the HOLD position even though it needs at least a couple of two beating consecutive earning quarters to be absolute. The market is very competitive and AAPL lost its luster and the mighty smart phone is not mighty any more. Adding to that AAPL must work hard on plans prices not to be unaffordable. Students are about 50-70% of the smart phone market and find it unaffordable. I myself and my three boys 2 of them shifted their phones from IPHONES to GALAXY SIII and the third is waiting the end of his contract to join. In one family AAPL is loosing 4 iphones to GALAXY just because of the plan price. AAPL must move quickly and be reasonable to gain back its customers and that takes 2 years for the end of the contracts. I hope AAPL learned a valuable lesson. GOOD LUCK.

Message.Title: AAPL CEO doesn't care if the stock drop in price. he thank me for taking the price down
Message.Msg: Apple (AAPL) took a 63 point nosedive after management reported earnings. RAYSTOCK doesn't think it was the declining gross margins or questions about market share that hurt the company the most, but the arrogance of management, which gave analysts the impression that the company doesn't need to justify itself. RAYSTOCK thinks that Apple is resting on its laurels because of its past greatness, and the once-growth company is now becoming more of a value stock; "Perhaps the guys at Apple don't even care." RAYSTOCK issued an open memo to Apple: Do something with your cash. Apple could be helped with a buyback, a dividend or an acquisition, but he doesn't see much upside in the stock for the short term. ::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::

Topic.Title: Cramer is right on.....

Message.Msg: For once Cramer shacked it: Apple (AAPL) took a 63 point nosedive after management reported earnings. Cramer doesn't think it was the declining gross margins or questions about market share that hurt the company the most, but the arrogance of management, which gave analysts the impression that the company doesn't need to justify itself. Cramer thinks that Apple is resting on its laurels because of its past greatness, and the once-growth company is now becoming more of a value stock; "Perhaps the guys at Apple don't even care." Cramer issued an open memo to Apple: Do something with your cash. Apple could be helped with a buyback, a dividend or an acquisition, but he doesn't see much upside in the stock for the short term.

Message.Title: Watched Cramer last night to see what he'd say about Apple!
Message.Msg: At no time during his ranting did he say "sell!" He made a few negative comments about the quarter but more than anything he was making an open statement to Apple management to put the cash to work (BUYBACK and DIVIDEND). I don't think the growth story has stagnated as much as Wall Street would like to tell us! I don't think the Quarter was bad whatsoever but the guidance admittedly was a little lame. Maybe Cook doesn't want us to know just how much Samsung is nipping at Apple's heels! I'm looking at it this way. If you got 500 shares in your IRA you currently are getting $5,600 per year in dividend. In just 4 YEARS even if the stock were to stay at current levels that's $22,200 just in dividends and the dividend is going to be up from here! I believe March guidance probably isn't blockbuster and June may be better in their seasonal cycle. Just my opinion of course but I'm not buying this whole negative BS story Wall Street is pushing down my throat! New products, higher dividends, buyback, adding China Mobile, yada yada! Apple isn't finished yet!!!!

Message.Title: The Real Problem is Tim Cook
Message.Msg: When Steve Jobs took over Apple, it was in a bad shape. He revamped its product line and came out with iPod, which was an instant hit. Then, he built iMac, and the iPhone followed later. Jobs hired right people for right jobs. Today's success is pretty much achieved by Jobs's countless efforts. Cook is pretty much living off his legacy. He hasn't done anything and hasn't proved anything. Steve emphasized on innovation and design, which are no way to be found in the Cook-era. Anyway, if Cook can't figure the problem out in three quarters, then we can assume that he is incapable. Not even the world largest tech company can't withstand its management's lack of vision.

The story is not over it really is just getting started.

Topic.Title: So what went wrong?

Message.Msg: Your comments are superficial and reflect a lack of knowledge on important dynamics for the company. As for my other posts, other than discussing DeMark's excellent history on AAPL, now soured by the poor cc handling which gave the shorts and and other "exhausted" sellers a final gasping breath reason to press for another day or three, almost nothing I've discussed in detail has anything to do with "pumping" anything. As an aside, we also noted -- before the CC -- that DeMark's calls on the overall market have not been so solid, noting that his call for a 5% market correction three weeks ago has missed the mark as the dow transports kicked that in the face and now strong earnings by key participants (including as yet unappreciated AAPLs) have overcome the adverse reaction to poor handling of topics on the CC (note the technical and quant orientation there?) Moreover, miles apart from repeating mere "pump" on my key posts over the last month here, since earlyOctober much of what I've written has been critical of the cfo and the IR staff and lack of transparency, really weak thinking on capital management, and sharing perspective on what many capital management funds, including ours, have done to hedge and then pull the hedge on serious long positions here. Additionally, if you read our post on earnings modelling here, you'll note we were only 1m iPads high, right within target with our $48-50B rev est and only missed on margin -- way better than most sellsiders and others who've been very accurate over time. If you can't decipher what a key point in this thread, we pulled off almost half of the hedge when Gore telegraphed that is at least his advisors think a big move higher is coming before March 19; the CC effd that otherwise irrefutable logic for for a day or four. As of last night, we are back to 100% long. Have at your dartboard daytrading though - we'll continue to focus on fundamental and quantitative analysis as well as chart studies.

Message.Title: Value Investors Not Buying This Dip Says Brian White At Topeka Capital Market
Message.Msg: Analyst Brian White at Topeka Capital Market said the lack interest from value-oriented investors, who look for bargain stocks, means Apple lacks a safety net when there’s bad news, like Wednesday’s earnings report. When other companies’ stocks fall, value investors tend to swoop in, putting a floor under the stock and dampening volatility. “No one wants to pay anything for (Apple) because you can’t get the value investor to back it up,” White said. Apple sits on a cash pile of $137 billion, which currently earns about 1 per cent annual interest. It’s a hoard that frustrates many company-watchers, and analysts are virtually unanimous in their opinion that Apple should be putting it to better use.

Message.Msg: It is rare for a stock to bounce the second day after a massive selloff. Topic.Title: PM Bid / Ask Opened at $452 / $453

Message.Msg: Hang in there Coffee. I read another post by you, and I know things seem desperate now, they will get better. Remember, many people are in the same boat as you (or even worse!). Heck I made a big (for me) short term options call play that had me up $13k+ going into earnings. I bought some Feb 550 calls Tuesday, was up $13k Wednesday afternoon, literally had my screen open to sell them out to lock in my gains, and got greedy and decided not to pull the trigger. Well, earnings "missed" and this pig got slaughtered, and I'm more than likely looking at a huge loss (40k+), when I had a big gain locked up. It sucks, especially because I absolutely knew better, but getting greedy and going for the home run clouded my judgement. Even if AAPL hovers around $450 and you lose your call option money, your shares of AAPL will come back. If it's too stressful for you, just sell them, and chalk everything up to an expensive education. It absolutely sucks to be on the wrong side of this and being in margin compounds it, but in the long run things will be fine. Personally, being greedy and stupid on this play will have wiped out most of my gains I've made in the past two years. Has it bothered me and caused me to not sleep well the past couple of nights? Yes. Will I learn from it, and not make the same mistake again? For Sure. Even with this loss, do I still have it better than 99% of the people that have ever walked this planet? Absolutely. Ultimately, we have to remember that.

Message.Title: Stock buyback accounting
Message.Msg: So many of you want apple to increase stock buyback but have you looked at the actual effect of buyback? Lets assume Apple buys back $1B worth of stock this quarter at yesterday’s closing price of $450. $1B can buy about 2.22M shares which reduces the outstanding share number to about 938M. But Apple also has to charge the cost of buyback (about $1.06 per share) to this quarter's earning as required by GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles). At 11 P/E, that $1.06 charge will reduce the share price by $11. To deal with this kind of situations, many companies will report two sets of earning numbers - a GAAP earning which includes the charge, and a non-GAAP earning which excludes the one-time charge. They want people to ignore the GAAP numbers. Some traders will indeed ignore that but some will not. Also, if it is going to buy back $1B each quarter for the next 10 quarters, that charge will be recurring and no longer be one time, and the hit on stock price will also accumulate. So don’t expect stock buyback will always have positive effect on stock, it may not.

Message.Title: Growth Investors Not Buying This Dip They Have "Moved On" Says Nomura Analyst
Message.Msg: “The company is at a bit of a crossroads,” said Nomura Securities analyst Stuart Jeffrey. “It’s gone from launching big hit products where they didn’t have to look at the competitive landscape — they just did their own thing — and the growth meant they didn’t have to focus on the whims of Wall Street.” The problem, Jeffrey said, is that Apple hasn’t adjusted to this reality and worked to find new constituencies among investors. Those who invest in fast-growing companies or chase rising stocks have abandoned the company, and Apple doesn’t do enough to attract value and income investors.

Message.Msg: Samsung did really well until AAPL began selling the i5. Those who actually study Samsung also understand that because they sell their calzone sized phones at cost to WMT shopping fashion-conscious women, the only thing they really generate operating earnings on in the mobile space is sales of chipsets to AAPL. Stay tuned for that, but AAPL is pulling the business away from Samsung and beyond damage awards for copying aapl patetns on some areas of mibile, they will likely soon be subject to paying a per device royalty to aapl just like HTC has already agreed to do. Topic.Title: AAPL is gonna have to prove itself in earnings

Message.Msg: There was always 'Irrational exuberance' around Apple. This can also be applied to Amazon, Google, etc... They are still making money. Apple missed Analyst expections, which are always very optimistic. The challenge, to all the Computer tech companies, is the next be thing. Screen sizes and apps for passing data is not innovative. At this time forward it will be about the quality and value. Apple provides very good products. I have 5+ year old Apple products (ipod nano's, touches, iMAC, macBook, iPhone, ). For me they are worth what I payed. My two year old company supplied PC is dying already. So much for the Win/Tel competition.

Topic.Title: Growth Investors Not Buying This Dip They Have "Moved On" Says Nomura Analyst

Message.Msg: "White has been one of the biggest Apple cheerleaders on Wall Street. He drew attention in April for setting a $1,111 price target for Apple’s stock when the shares were trading around $600. White backed away from his old price target on Thursday. He said he still believes the company is worth that much, but he has realized he’s too far in front of the pack. Investors aren’t going to give the company the credit it deserves, in his opinion. “It’s tough for people to get their head around. I can’t be a visionary forever,” White said. His new price target: $888. Eight is a lucky number in China, and three eights are extra lucky. “Look, Apple needs a little luck here,” White said.

Message.Msg: Tim Cook is a big reason for Apple's huge success in the past 2-3 years. Steve was the man, but Tim was the supply chain wizard. This will work it's self out in the coming quarter or two. The media is fabricating news to drive Apple down. They say Apple missed revenue and EPS but don't like to mention the quarter was 14 weeks last year but only 13 weeks this year. That makes a big difference. Blood is in the water right now and it is great to buy AAPL at a forward P/E of 7.98

Message.Title: Lots of posters here are still in love with Apple stock
Message.Msg: You guys come out defending your love one anyway you can. I understand that. But trading is about making money not about falling in love. The recent drop is ultimately caused by institutions pulling out of Apple and moving money into better stocks. When institutions sell, they don't sell in just one or two days. They sell over many months. So don't expect AAPL will have a V shape turnaround. It won't. And please take a step back, look around, and ask yourself: are there better stocks out there that will give better return for the next 6 to 12 months?

Message.Title: So tired of every one beatching about Apple's cash hoard
Message.Msg: Why does Apple hoard cash? Ever heard of Motorola? What about the multiple other tech companies out there whose products did not innovate fast enough who did not have hoards of cash to re-innovate itself. Even Apple was in this situation before Steve Jobs came back to re-invent the business. Here is the philosophy. Tech is constantly transitioning through innovation. If as a tech company you do not innovate your product line fast enough, or if development is made that renders your products not as desirable, you must re-innovate yourself to compete by creating new technologies/products/applications. As long as Apple has hundreds of billions in cash, it will never find itself like Motorola. Even Rimm and Yahoo are in this same boat. They attack Apple for its stash of cash because should Apple lower its cash it becomes that much more vulnerable. As long as it is sitting on a mountain of cash these wall street swine will NEVER be able to destroy it. Stop beatching about the cash, the brilliance behind this hoard is to make certain the filth of Wall Street is never able to slice Apple from ear to ear like it has done to countless other companies. I am quite certain this is why Steve Jobs never wanted to pay a dividend and hoarded his cash as much as he possibly could.

Message.Title: Most Funds Holding Apple Have A Yearly Round Trip And A Finger On "Sell @ Market" Key
Message.Msg: Daniel Loeb is sitting on 20% paper losses from his average purchase price since opening a position in the first quarter of 2012 at $504 a share. He has entered an exited the stock at profitable points in the past, however. His reason for coming back to Apple appeared in his first quarter 2012 letter: “Following Apple’s December quarter earnings, we re‐established a position in the stock at $445 per share, a level 10% up from the pre‐earnings price. While the market reacted positively to the strong results, we believed it was still not discounting adequately the strong likelihood that Apple would return capital in 2012. The prospect of capital return stood to broaden the investor base enabling the market capitalization to re‐base around an attractive dividend profile, particularly relative to the Company’s growth rate. Beyond the capital return catalyst, we were focused on Apple’s entry into the 4G device space in 2012, led by the latest iPad and the pending iPhone 5,” he wrote.

Topic.Title: Total ridiculousness

Message.Msg: I agree. It is actually rather frightening how Wall Street is able to decide to systematically take apart a stock. I don't think the argument is that Apple is growing as quickly as it has over the past 5 - 8 years, it is not. The argument is that the stock price is absolutely laughable. An operating P/E of 8, really? It's not as if people are arguing that the stock should be trading at nose-bleed levels (like Amazon, which is another ridiculous story in itself) with an unattainable and stupid P/E (like Amazon or some others). It is simply that Apple should, at the absolulte least, trade with the market which would put the stock price at around $750. It is a shame that the small investor cannot count on doing their research, finding great, well run companies with great businesses, that deliver consistent revenue and earnings, all the things Apple is doing and doing better than 99% of the companies out there, and then invest in those companies and make some money because the stock is valued appropriately. That's the real crime here. The small investor gets raped by Wall Street once again.

Topic.Title: I predict that Apple stock will fall to its true market value of $280 PPS. Sorry Apple, the CON is over!!!!

Message.Msg: Samsung Dominated Apple And Nokia With A Record 213 Million Smartphones Shipped In 2012 January 25, 2013 | includes: AAPL, NOK, SSNLF.PK By Jordan #$%$ The battle's been raging between Samsung (SSNLF.PK) and Apple (AAPL) for global smartphone domination. But according to the latest numbers from Strategy Analytics, Samsung has extended its lead over rival manufacturers to capture a 30% marketshare worldwide. According to the research firm, Samsung's 213 million smartphones shipped over the course of 2012 sets a record for most units shipped by a smartphone vendor in a single year. The previous record holder was Nokia (NOK), which shipped 100.1 million units in 2010. Samsung's ability to deliver both on the high end (with the Galaxy S III and Galaxy Note II) and on the low end (with models like the Galaxy Y) made the Korean firm nearly impossible to beat. In fact, Samsung sold more smartphones this year than Apple and Nokia combined. Apple continued to see growth, despite rumors that iPhone 5 part production cutbacks were a sign of low demand, shipping 135.8 million smartphones worldwide and capturing a market share of 19% globally. That represents 46% annual growth in units shipped. However, it doesn't seem to have done much for Apple's market share, which was at a steady 19% in 2011 as well. Samsung and Apple combined shipped over half of all smartphones that went out over the course of the year. Nokia managed to hang on to its third place position, shipping 35 million smartphones in 2012. However, the Finnish phone giant's market share dipped from 16% last year to a mere 5% this year. Hopefully the company's partnership with Microsoft (MSFT) and the budding Lumia line can help in plugging up that leak.

Topic.Title: Why do you people watch CNBC?

Message.Msg: I'll give you a serious answer, because I (and almost everyone on these boards) used to think this way. We are sheep. We think we are smart, but really are afraid to admit to ourselves we are clueless when it comes to stocks. We are still sheep. 97% of self directed investors underperform the market, and by an average of 50%. We are still sheep. We think we can get all the knowledge we need by watching Jim Cramer for an hour. We are STILL sheep. In general terms, investing in stocks is a sucker's game. We are no longer sheep. Sheep are now smarter than we are. I never met a poor broker or a rich investor. The sheep are now our masters. I have met plenty of smart brokers and dumb investors. Now, this is why I never invest in individual stocks anymore. I invest in conservative mutual funds and am doing fine. I sleep well, and no longer spend 20 hours a week doing stock research. I spend that time playing golf and with my grandchildren on vacation. I no longer watch CNBC. I am no longer a sheep.

Topic.Title: we dipped our toe in the water at 445... very small trade...

Message.Msg: we haven't given any respect to analysts targets... its been that way since the early 90s... the game is just too overwhelming for them... its hard enough for insiders to know what is exactly going on with the company and their stock price... so for trading purposes we gauge our guesses on what the chart tells us... so for today since we got involved at 445-ish we will use the day-low as a stop-out... risk a point for the possibility of closing positive or getting a rally sometime today and even give it a chance to close over 448 the dreaded-dead-or-alive-#... its actually a close over the lower-447's but we can't be so stringent after a giant-wipe-out of the stock price... but if it closes under that 447 then we will close out the Buy-444-Trade... if it closes positive we will hold the Buy-444-Trade... if it closes on or just over 448 then we will probably exit since the stock has been beaten down for 2 days without a single whimper of a rally when the SPX filled the 5-Year-Highest-Gap

Message.Title: From Msft 10Q
Message.Msg: "OSD’s operating loss was reduced by higher revenue and lower cost of revenue and sales and marketing expenses, offset in part by higher research and development expenses. Cost of revenue decreased $163 million, driven by lower traffic acquisition costs and Yahoo! reimbursement costs. Sales and marketing expenses decreased $71 million or 19%, due mainly to decreased advertising and corporate marketing activities. Research and development expenses increased $47 million or 8%, primarily reflecting higher headcount-related expenses." Seems to be saying YHOO will be reporting less search income. I sure hope the float has been reduced enough to offset that shortfall in operating income if, infact, there is a shortfall.

Topic.Title: stock movement

Message.Msg: unlike many of the mindless fools and the cheerleaders who seemingly know all, i am not that omniscient to know the value of the shares of this company. i trade options, anywhere from 20 to more than 100 per day, and i spread, and i minimize risk, i look at the charts, i look at volatility and the greeks, and buy undervalued and sell overvalued. a couple days ago it was clearly a buy when a gap was almost 100% filled-close enough for me. i watch order flow. bottom line is trading the technicals and the valuations of the derivative is far more fruitful than figuring worth. i do take long and short biases based on these factoids and others such as the overall market. with this company the micros are far more important than the market macros, but one cannot lose sight of the latter as 70% + of all stocks go the direction of the market. good luck. hope the stock goes in the direction that you want.

Message.Title: interesting article
Message.Msg: it is from the investorscopes blog Apple - Was the Writing on the Wall? Yesterday Apple reported revenues lighter than expected, as sales of iPhones, iPads and Macs missed Street projections, and the company’s March quarter guidance came in well below Street expectations. Not surprisingly, the stock price plunged today in one of the biggest declines in years. Is there any data not widely recognized that could have pointed to changes ahead? The following chart is a comparsion of the keyword "android" vs. "iphone" over the last two years from all form 10-Q, form 10-K and form 8-K filings from the thousands of public companies required to file with the SEC. As you can see, the Iphone was being referenced more for some time until early 2012, when a distinct change occured. More companies started mentioning "android", and that trend has continued. Perhaps this was coincidental and didn't have anything to do with the weak numbers and future guidance now given. Or maybe, Portfolio Managers and individual investors alike would be well served to pay attention to trends in the textual content of public comany filiings as well as the reported numbers....

Topic.Title: Darn. Bought at 460 after earnings thinking I was a genius

Message.Msg: You can't just buy into any rebound. A rebound doesn't take out the pervious resistance is just a dead cat bounce in a downtrend - that is what downtrend means, lower highs and lower lows. When it tested and bounced off supports, a reversal maybe in place. When it breaks out of resistance, a reversed trend is developing. I also recommend you pay attention to candlestick patterns. Candlestick is very good at spotting trend reversal. It will help you decide which reversal is more likely to success.

Message.Title: MY MEMO TO APPLE CORPORATE:
Message.Msg: Text of my message: Myself, as well as many investors, are convinced that Mr. Cook has run his course as CEO, and that new, innovative blood is necessary to move our company forward. I would like to communicate my personal disdain for the arrogant attitude that Mr. Cook is exhibiting in the face of the huge debacle that HE has led in the share destruction of Apple. ALL investors are being hurt here, including all Apple employees, who have placed their trust in Mr. Cook and the executive team. I won't bother to itemize the list of blatant mistakes and errors in judgement that have been perpetrated by Mr. Cook's leadership; others inside and outside the media have done so already. I will conclude by saying that I feel it is time that the Board Of Directors take a fresh look at this company's situation, in light of Mr. Cook's incompetent leadership, and begin an executive overhaul that is long overdue. Best Rgds, ..........

Message.Title: Well Said
Message.Msg: My biggest question for the last two months has been, “how in the world can a stock lose 25% of its value (now 37%) from highs yet expectations remain the same?” The company sold 47.8 million iPhones, the street was expecting $48 million; revenue was $54.5 billion which was $200 million shy of expectations; and earnings were greater than expectations; so therefore what created the loss? Overall, it was a great quarter with 26.7% top-line growth adjusted for the extra week in the quarter. With that being said, I am not sure what the market wants from a company this large with a single digit forward P/E ratio. It’s a simple fact that as a company grows larger year-over-year sales will decline. The fact that it’s expecting 20-30% growth as a company with over $155 billion in sales is quite extraordinary. Bottom line: The market got this one wrong, it should have risen 10% on such incredible growth.

Message.Title: Alcoa World Alumina and Chemicals is also known as AWAC. It is a global alumina business that is a joint venture between Alumina Limited (40% owned) and Alcoa Inc, (60% owned).
Message.Msg: Alcoa World Alumina and Chemicals is also known as AWAC. It is a global alumina business that is a joint venture between Alumina Limited (40% owned) and Alcoa Inc, (60% owned). AWAC has an international network of alumina refineries in the United States, Brazil, Suriname, Jamaica, Spain and Australia. AWAC is a recognized industry market leader with approximately 15% of world alumina production capacity. Around 90% of this alumina goes to feed smelters that produce the aluminium used in transport, aerospace, building, construction and packaging.

Topic.Title: Well Said

Message.Msg: Apple is trading on emotion and momentum, not fundamentals. I have 600 shares at $499, so the past few days have been irritating, to say the least. It's not going to go down forever, although it feels that way now. All it will take is a single positive catalyst and it will bounce back quickly. My brother-in-law is a hedge fund guy who is rooting for Apple to keep falling so he can get in at a bigger discount. The retail guys are the ones selling now. The big guys sold at $700. Once they decide to get back in, the people on this board who pretend that they're shorting the stock but aren't because their brokerage accounts are too light to allow them to short stocks, will fade away. And to the people that actually did short the stock, good for you. Smart call.

Topic.Title: People, buybacks are gimmicks for desperate people

Message.Msg: We've just gone through a period of rapid technological improvements in mobile "computing" with the maturation of the smartphone. We're now going to experience a loooong period of stagnation with only minor incremental improvements in processor power and energy efficiency and possibly improvements in imaging. Apple is now #$%$ because nobody is going to continue paying a premium for stagnant improvements. Apple is a 2 product company, and their only hope is to expand into TVs, which is a low margin business with long consumer purchase cycles.

Topic.Title: Einhorn + AAPL

Message.Msg: Agreed.. but the problem is, 'they' (media, bashers, etc) think the proper valuation is 350 to 420... that is a huge problem. I've always felt (going back to 2011) that 'proper valuation' for AAPL was 631 to 659. I felt supercharged when it ran upwards of that. But this latest 38%+ retracing downwards is a Death Spiral and no one is there to throw out a safety net. Surely when one sells, another is buying. But the fact remains, for this stock position to achieve back to the 630s/650s where it should be, will require a 40% run to the upside. Do you really think AAPL has a chance to make that happen in 2013? After their pathetic management arrogance and condescending "be like Steve Jobs " attitude (which I could take from Jobs himself), then the collapse wed/thur and further horrible guidance for next quarter... there's only one way this stock will go (hint: it's the antonym of "up"). When the rest of the market is making new 52 wk highs this early in the year (some surely don't deserve this, not even remotely) and AAPL crashes/burns... or as I think : SELF-IMMOLATES... what's the chance of a strong recovery? Pretty damned futile. And I'm being optimistic. I've always love Apple products and been a 'Long' since 2003. However this current apathetic condition does not bode well for 12-18 months... and quite possibly, beyond that. Where is the Head of Retail? Oh, they still haven't filled that position? #$%$? As much as I absolutely detest saying this, I believe (now) AAPL is an immediate SELL. They've got to get their act together - yes, for shareholders. It would be easy to put a finger in the wall and stop the gushing of water. Make a media appearance Cook, on ALL the BS shows that spew negativity. Surely that's not Jobs/ angle (but YOU aren't Jobs). I mark AAPL, a SELL. Hopefully a true bottom will be achieved, a new pipeline of superior products gets released and the momentum comes back. I would hope...

Message.Title: The "problem" with Apple. Below is my response to a (another) CNBC hit piece.
Message.Msg: The problem for Apple will continue to be the unparalleled media prejudice against this company since its recent top. Anyone following the name knows that media, for clicks and views, has become the willing accomplice to the downturn in the price action. Without exaggeration, a new negative 're-hash' article surfaces every 5 to 10 minutes and often, more frequently. For example, have you seen reports that focus on the extra week comparative data and how that is skewing results. Where is the headline, "One Billion a Week in Profit" or "Apple doubles China sales"? Topic.Title: I need serious help... please help..... I'm truthfully speaking here so I please be kind.

Message.Msg: At some point, Apple will bounce. with or without new product announcements. However, nobody can predict the bottom nor how far it will bounce. It's such a bargain now that I'm mystified that it's still dropping. Anyway, I've been in a margin squeeze and I waited too long to deal with it and my brokerage nearly ruined me (this was many years ago). You might sell some shares to reduce margin but if you wait for the brokerage to step in they might liquidate your entire position. That's what happened to me. Here's what FINRA says: Your firm can force the sale of securities in your accounts to meet a margin call Your firm can sell your securities without contacting you You are not entitled to choose which securities or other assets in your accounts are sold Your firm can increase its margin requirements at any time and is not required to provide you with advance notice You are not entitled to an extension of time on a margin call You can lose more money than you deposit in a margin account Once you address the margin issue, you may simply want to hold for the long term (that's what I'm doing). You can't predict the future and Apple might make a big announcement and suddenly the shares are energized. I can't advise you on the options since I don't trade them. Good luck.

Message.Title: Patience is needed
Message.Msg: From CS Apple. Inc. (AAPL) OUTPERFORM K. Garcha CP: US$ 514.17 TP: US$ 600 CAP: US$ 484.7b Patience required, structurally solid; Lowering Estimates and TP to $600 (from $750)  Reiterate O/P, lower TP to $600. We lower FY13/14 EPS by 13%/15%, to $47.90/$58.18, and TP to $600 (from $750). We believe a lower ability to beat EPS expectations, and some concerns on demand, may weigh on the stock near-term. Fundamentally, with a structural advantage in the compute market, Apple should deliver robust EPS growth of 16%. Trading on a P/E 9x our CY13 EPS, the stock is inexpensive, in our opinion, given $145 of net cash per share.  Three steps to a recovery: none coming imminently, patience required. First, a new product cycle (we expect a high-end iPhone refresh and lower end iPhone later in 2013). Second, increased carrier expansion: while this is clearly happening slower than we thought, we still believe it's likely over 12 months. Third, increased cash distribution: Apple ended the quarter with $137bn of net cash some ~30% of market cap and 31% onshore so the capacity to distribute exits. While all these catalysts are plausible, none are imminent in our view, meaning patience is required.  iPhone growth drivers exist. Volumes were 47.8mn up 29% yoy/ 78% qoq in-line with street estimates. Going forward, we see volumes of 177mn/212mn in 2013/2014 driven by several factors. First, we see continued growth in the high-end of the smartphone market. Second, we see carrier expansion growing annual units by 65mn. Third, while the innovation gap at the high-end has narrowed, Apple sustains a compute advantage.  Set to dominate the fast growing tablet space. iPad volumes of 22.9mn were strong, up 48% yoy and 63% qoq. We believe Apple captured 56% of the tablet market and we increasingly see the company sustaining a ~50% share in the segment given 3 factors: (1) a superior compute experience/ecosystem across smartphones, tablets and PC's; (2) a tablet product

Topic.Title: Einhorn + AAPL

Message.Msg: I think we' re actually mostly in agreement here, but my point is that WS has no soul - they only respond to profits and if Apple (Big IF) keeps putting up profit numbers like they have, WS will buy the stock again - they must - it's in their DNA. p/e can't go to 0 unless b/k is assured, which it is ridiculous, and even then, $137B in the bank with little no debt, puts a floor under pps. Sure, they have to innovate, Market likes big phones, so they have to address that, just like they came out with the iPad mini to address market need. I did not like Cooks's and Oppenheimer's smug, inward-focused tone on the CC either - we'll see what happens there. Point is that NBC bashing is a short-term depress pps ploy and will not drive a good company out of business as long as they continue to produce profits - huge profits. So best thing Apple can do is to make great new products...along with some shareholder friendly-moves

Topic.Title: Einhorn + AAPL

Message.Msg: Absolutely agree. I simply wish I had sold everything in September (I actually HAD my finger on the SELL button at 693, but every damned person was screaming 750 and the new iP5 wasn't put yet, nor was the holiday season even ringing in yet), instead I 'waited' for the big holiday crush-the-street numbers like i've always done. I sold my entire position at open this AM. Too much bloodshed; yes made a 'decent' gain since 2009, but if you saw what I left on the table by not selling in Sept. you'd vomit. I didn't want to see AAPL collapse and I'm not one of the many idiots that want to see it plummet further and scream BS to other folks losing. I had a gain. But my gain 'was' double today's gain, back in Sept. Greed wasn't my ploy/tactic. ALL the numbers, pundits etc et al were saying much higher than my 714 sell target. I simply missed it and wished the stock back up. Will I get back in? Got to say that I'm trying to find some 'fast money' tickets to get my 35% left on the table back, ASAP. And AAPL will take quite the long time to recover 35-40%. DDD is a company I recently threw money at as I was watching AAPL drop back in December. I'm up 40% on DDD in less than 45 days. Go figure. Could have sold all my shares of AAPL dumped them in DDD (a big gamble sure) but... now look at NFLX (ridiculous) and even ISRG making big runs... That's what I'm looking for after holding AAPL all these years.. and lost my Feb 11 divi by selling too... so...?

Topic.Title: I need serious help... please help..... I'm truthfully speaking here so I please be kind.

Message.Msg: To the ending your life quesiton: I was very depressed for months once, financially screwed, in a miserable place with a job that I hated, few close friends, and some very mediocre prospects for the future. Every day I took the train to work, and every day I stood at the very end of the platform where the train comes in and pictured myself leaping in front of the train as it arrived. One day during this period I had a dream. I was in these caverns deep underground, I knew someone was looking for me, and I was looking for them. Finally we encountered eachother in one of the twisting turnnels. It was a mirror image of me. The mirror image angrily said to me "DO IT, or stop thinking about it!" I'm in no way suggesting that you "do it," and I don't think that was what the dream was meant to imply. The dream just meant that I had a choice, if I was going endit, then end it, but otherwise it was time to make a commitment to life and stop viewing suicide as a viable solution. I took it off the table, and whenever I found my thoughts creeping in that direction, to remember that I had already made my decision, I had commited to life and no matter how difficult it got I wasn't going to end it that way. I hope you make the same decision, but in the end, it's your life. On the question of the stock value: While I think that Apple is weak right now, I don't believe they are anywhere near as bad as people think. This company has been written off as dead many times and has always come back. The question I ask myself, is there any facts out there that jusify a 52-week low? Because they haven't released any new products recently and their Quarterly results weren't all that great? This company is still extremely diverse, with a variety of products and revenue streams, and has the potiential to create a true IT ecosystem for its users. I think the stock is going to rise, but I personally don't think more than 550 is reasonable any time soon. Just my opinion though.

Topic.Title: Advice on selling

Message.Msg: Apple is a global brand. It has, by itself, a loyal following that appreciates its innovations, its quality, and its app ecosystem. Apple managed to survive three decades as the lone alternative to PCs and now it has a war chest of $135 billion, nosebleed operating margins and cash flow. Should its current products transition to commodities, it will still hold those loyalties for a long, long time. And who knows what new products/services will be part of that brand, five and ten years from now? I can think of several areas where they can focus R&D and M&A where current available products/services are lacking or dismal, inviting their legacy. Alternatively, Cook was the first to put a dividend out there as a recent development -- Apple certainly has the means to make ownership a long-term, sound investment.

Topic.Title: Mr. Cook had one sentence during conference call everyone ignored

Message.Msg: Violence of the selloff is truly impressive. Illustrates far more how market is almost totally driven by momentum and technical analysis. This is not to say there are not fundamental challenges embedded in this story because they are certainly there. But the expectation that you can have a major innovation every year is crazy. Innovation does not simply take place in product development. It can occur anywhere. I am hoping the Cook can work out a financial arrangement with China Mobile that will work for both companies. The days of sky high margins are probably over but it is impossible to maintain them in any free enterprise economy. The worst thing APPL can do is be influenced by the price action of its stock. This is a very painful chapter but the book is not quite finished. I still have a lot of APPL and my basis is 11 bucks. The only thing that really bothered me was the maps screw-up. It is things like that which will get me out of the stock. The traders just do what they do. They have only one playbook and they have to exit when something like this happens.

Message.Title: I agree w/Cramer for once
Message.Msg: “Apple (AAPL) took a 63 point nosedive after management reported earnings. Cramer doesn’t think it was the declining gross margins or questions about market share that hurt the company the most, but the arrogance of management, which gave analysts the impression that the company doesn’t need to justify itself [via Jim Cramer's Mad Money TV program on CNBC, Thursday January 24.],” Miriam Metzinger reports for Seeking Alpha. “Cramer thinks that Apple is resting on its laurels because of its past greatness, and the once-growth company is now becoming more of a value stock; ‘Perhaps the guys at Apple don’t even care,’” Metzinger reports. “Cramer issued an open memo to Apple: Do something with your cash. Apple could be helped with a buyback, a dividend or an acquisition, but he doesn’t see much upside in the stock for the short term.”

Message.Title: I kept saying to sell AAPL for months and months
Message.Msg: If you listened, you're welcome. But this earnings was the most obvious disaster-waiting-to-happen in a long time. There was almost no way the stock didn't tank. And the bewildering strength in the stock over the last few weeks could only be due to speculators and retail stupids. And that makes me think that there is a really good chance this stock sees a violent downmove soon, straight down into the $300's. A lot of #$%$ analysts were just upgrading this stock to $1000. Everyone you know and their grandmother owns the stock. The headlines are now turning negative but all those poor saps are going to try to hang on, while institutional sellers bail. Short-term speculators are going to start dumping within 2-3 days (margin calls come in at that time). I figure retail stupids will start selling at $350. So if you want to buy AAPL, I suggest you wait till $300-325. At that point AAPL will be universally hated and might actually be worth a look. Don't bother before then, unless they come out with something as new and exciting as the iPhone was when it first came out. mothra

Message.Title: The iPad 5 Will Launch In October And Look Completely Different
Message.Msg: " iLounge's Jeremy Horwitz reports Apple's fifth-generation iPad will launch in October with a brand new design. Horwitz says he's seen a model of the new iPad, but isn't sure if it's the final version. Still, the design is very similar to the iPad Mini, so it'll be thinner and lighter with rounded edges and aluminum backing. Horwitz also claims Apple's next iPhone will look very similar to the current iPhone 5 but have a larger camera flash on the back. Apple will also release a cheaper iPhone made of plastic. Keep in mind Horwitz isn't always accurate with Apple reports. However, he's been correct in the past, so it's worth mentioning."

Message.Title: OMG: Samsung reshaping pixels to create ultra-dense HD displays
Message.Msg: Samsung reshaping pixels to create ultra-dense HD displays When it comes to hi-res displays, using traditional methods it is nearly impossible to squeeze more than 440 pixels per inch into a typically-zied smartphone screen. Samsung’s upcoming Full HD Super AMOLED display — said to be the centerpiece of the Galaxy S4 — just about reaches the limit. That screen measures 4.99 inches, but Samsung is looking into ways to bring a similar pixel density to smaller screen sizes. How do they plan on accomplishing this? By reinventing the pixel. Current screen technology uses square pixels, and only so many can be crammed into a display before the rules of geometry take over. But those same rules of geometry are being used to reshape the pixel in a way that will allow for more on smaller screens, perhaps at a clip even greater than 440 ppi. According to a report from DigiTimes, Samsung is experiminting with hexagonal and diamond-shaped pixels as a replacement for square pixels. But will the additional pixels be more than chum for the advertising department? It is said that the human eye maxes out at around 300 pixels, hence the Retina display moniker Apple has attached to its 326 ppi iPhone display. But in a smartphone race based on gigahertz, megapixels, and screen resolution, Samsung will do what it has to do get a leg up on the competition, even if the end result makes no technical difference to our eyes.

Message.Msg: Actually, there IS a larger-screen iPhone "in the pipe", as our dearly beloved Cook sings. They need MORE than that. Topic.Title: What would Steve Jobs do in a time like this?

Message.Msg: No human has that streak of luck in professional life as Steve had, so there was definitely more to Steve Jobs than luck. People have hard time putting a finger on what it was. Another genius Bill Gates identified what it was, and said that Jobs had great instinct, whether hiring the right people or thinking of an idea, he followed his guts and was often right. No MBAs or supply chain human calculators can reengineer a music business into what itunes were able to do. No 'genius' Wall Street analyst thought iPad will be successful when launched, again Steve was right. What he would do right now if alive is he'd be busy materializing another beautiful product that people haven't realized that they have any use for, and then falling madly in love with. Jobs was guided by his creative gutfeeling while Cook is driven by his fear, fear of Wall st., fear of losing his job, fear of Samsung..

Message.Title: Samsung has set a much loftier goal of 500 million phones sold.
Message.Msg: Looking to expand its presence in the smartphone market, LG has set a modest but realistic sales goal for 2013. According to a report from the Korean Times, the manufacturer of the Optimus line of Android devices aims to move 75 million handsets this year. Of those, 45 million are projected to be smartphones. The figure seems like a drop in the bucket for competitors like Apple and Samsung. The latter just surpassed sales of 40 million for their Galaxy S3 flagship alone, which has been on the market for less than a year. Samsung has set a much loftier goal of 500 million phones sold. But for LG, it isn’t a bad idea to keep expectations tempered. The Korean company has yet to make a big splash in the mobile industry after a string of missed opportunities and poor decisions. 2012 was a better year for the company with 55 million handsets sold, but LG will need to capitalize on the success of devices such as the Optimus G and Nexus 4 if they want to become a true force in smartphone manufacturing.

Message.Title: Nexus 4 again out of stock at T-Mobile
Message.Msg: The Nexus 4, which only recently went back on sale via T-Mobile’s online store, is once again out of stock through the carrier’s web portal. The quickly sell out can no doubt be attributed to voracious Android fans looking to get their hands on the notoriously hard to find device. While the Nexus 4 wasn’t anticipated to sell near the level of phones like the Galaxy S3 and iPhone, it is clear that LG and Google grossly underestimated demand. Representatives from both sides say they are working hard to address the issues. A backlog of orders and even more customers waiting for the chance to make a purchase are making it quite difficult. Just imagine how many phones the two companies could have sold by now if they actually had any to sell.

Topic.Title: I need serious help... please help..... I'm truthfully speaking here so I please be kind.

Message.Msg: First of all, ANYONE who gives you a categorical yes or no to your question is talking off the top of his or her head. The price of aapl is determined by herd mentality, not by any rational consideration of its intrinsic or true "value." The company is a sound LONG-TERM BUY AND HOLD investment. However, you screwed yourself by "playing" with derivatives and margin purchases that you could not afford. So first and foremost, take this as a series of lessons: 1. Don't buy stocks with money you don't have. 2. Don't buy stocks with money you can't afford to lose. 3. Don't mess around with margins or derivatives until you reach the point where you can safely afford to lose your bet at the "worst case scenario" level. 4. Instead of "playing the market" you should learn about investing in stocks. What you are doing is not investing. It is gambling with borrowed money. And that's just plain dumb, for reasons that I hope have become obvious to you at this point in time. 5. Never put all your stock market money in only a small number of different companies or sectors, and NEVER put it all into a single company. OKAY.Now that you've learned the lessons, how do you get out of the mess you've put yourself into? AAPL is worth a lot more than it's selling for. That doesn't mean that you can sell it for what it's worth right now. But I would guess that there will be enough scooping-up of bargains by the sharks to drive the price up so that the market value will get back to $500/share by Feb. 16th. As soon as it does, start closing out the damn options. You shouldn't even be in options! Take what you can get & learn your lesson. Don't feel remorse if it goes up higher even after you close out the options. And get out of the margined stock! BTW, I increased my long position 50% today @ $449/sh (ncludes commissions); I expect it to get back over $500 in less than a month, then flatten out. But my AAPL is a tiny fraction of my portfolio, which is mostly dividend-growth stocks.

Topic.Title: So what went wrong?

Message.Msg: Here was part 2 that got pushed down 30 posts... it has the most important points: "New products are coming this year, margins are going to remain top of the heap, customers and carriers still want aapl over all others, IPad progress and proliferation is stunning and more coming, the wannabe tablets suk (see msft fail) and aapl's cloud and itunes with streaming on the way as well as iTV will all be part of the big turnaround coming for the shares. Did you guys pick up that icloud customers ramped to 250M + vs a year earlier at "only"150M? That is more than "flat line" and so is the app sales and service income line, even before the move of accessories down the income statement. Check out those itunes, service, accessories, and misc revenues guys -- likely to surpass $15B this year. I'll close by saying that at the ridiculous $400 target levels suggested by Cramer, Grundlach and even Misek and 25 other #$%$ in the CNBC bash ball today, aapl would be trading at a shipping or alcoa type of earning multiple of just 5x net of $150/share cash they presently have, and that is growing by more than $10B quarter! $10B PER QUARTER FRIENDS!!!! give me a f break... Adjusting out for the timing influences noted at the top, AAPL is still growing 3x faster than the S&P 500 AND ALREADY HAMMERED TO 7X... but here's the news of the day. AAPL is going to overcome these moronic valuation with performance, even if they need a real CFO and IR team to help Cook explain it. " I wrote that last night, today several blogs and others have paraphrased it because the stock is so ridiculously oversold. Love that Lazlo has the same take. LOL

Message.Title: For traders.... a snap back is on the horizon
Message.Msg: $35-$50 in about two to three days time.... Remember, in most cases with stocks like this, the upside is way overshot, and so is the downside. All us longs knew at $700 that we were playing with borrowed time and house money. Everyone of us. The stock climbed through $600 to $700 in what seemed like days. The same is happening here. Listen, the company is definitely maturing and going through some transition. But in two days following relatively strong earnings, the stock almost fell $100. Two days folks. Congrats to the shorts for the recent trend. But dont get complacent, as you will be making the same mistake as the long who took a position or didnt secure profits at $700. The snap back trade is coming. its just how the stock market works

Message.Title: EXPECT AAPL TO SETTLE IN AT $300 TO 350/SH
Message.Msg: Without any catalyst for significant growth, this will be the price range where AAPL should settle into. It will last for many years. Of course there will be ups and downs but if you look at other major technology companies, you will notice they have traded at approximately 1/2 of their all times highs once their meteoric run-ups ended. Apple declaring a dividend was the important hint that the run-up is over, which is typical of other tech giants when they have run out of catalysts for significant growth.

Message.Title: March 2012 EPS 12.30. March 2013 EPS 10.48 (estimate)
Message.Msg: That's the key story! In 2012 March quarter, Apple had 12.30 EPS and surprised by over 22%. For 2013 March quarter, Apple is projected to have 10.48 EPS, which is down 14.8%. Further, EPS estimates for current quarter have been going down... 90 days ago, EPS estimates were at 12.50. Analysts are pretty much saying that March quarter will be a wash and will show negative earnings growth. Apple has to come out strong and show that it can earn in excess of 12.30 EPS at the very least to have positive growth. Can Apple do that?

Message.Title: from NOV 7 2012... enjoy
Message.Msg: Why Apple Will Beat Estimates Next Quarter By Chad Henage - November 7, 2012 | Tickers: AAPL, GOOG, MSFT | 0 Comments Chad is a member of The Motley Fool Blog Network -- entries represent the personal opinions of our bloggers and are not formally edited. Mr. Market has a warped sense of what is disappointing. When Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL)released earnings recently, they were dubbed disappointing and led many to question if the company was going to make a habit of missing estimates. While it's true that Apple is running into tough comparisons, long-term investors are actually getting exactly what analysts have been predicting. For the last few years analysts have pegged Apple's EPS growth rate at around 20%; but when the company delivers on this expectation, investors are disappointed? The key to understanding Apple's earnings is knowing that consumers behave in a certain way. Those who understand the cycle of Apple's products can benefit from the drop in the stock when the company “disappoints,” and this is why I believe Apple will easily beat estimates next quarter. Current Quarter Results For The Big Two Products Were Mixed: Before we get to next quarter, let's look at the last three months to see just what happened. Apple reported sales up 27.21%, and EPS was up 22.98%. When you consider during the same quarter that competitors Google (NASDAQ: GOOG) and Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT)reported revenue growth of 18.58%, and a decline of 7.85%, respectively, the numbers look pretty darn good. The company's two major growth drivers are the iPhone and the iPad, and there were very specific dynamics that affected each. iPhone sales increased 56%, with unit growth of 58%. I'm sure a big part of the reason for this huge increase was the benefit of the end of quarter shipments of the iPhone 5. The quarter ended Sept. 29, and the iPhone 5 was introduced on Sept. 12. While recent IDC research suggests that Android is running about 75% of smartphones, this operating system is op

Message.Title: One Broken Stock
Message.Msg: I'm not sure why people don't look at technicals. Agreed news can override them but most of the time no. In all honesty there is true support above $350 and that's it. If the market turns sour and I expect it will what with all the printing of money no where for interest rates to go but up and recent retractions and lower global economic forecasts. The signs are there. the devaluation of the "petro-dollar"(US dollar) is beginning as countries like China are now buying oil with the yuan and other countries will follow. Countries are beginning to increase their gold reserves and showing 4th quarter retractions in their economy while forecasting lower growth. Today's report on the new home purchases is lowered. QE is becoming perpetual. All this being said if you're long I'd be hedging rather than adding more.

Topic.Title: What is keeping Apple from buying up their own cheap stock?

Message.Msg: Have you looked at the actual effect of stock buyback? Lets assume Apple buys back $1B worth of stock this quarter at today's closing price of $440. $1B can buy about 2.27M shares which reduces the outstanding share number to about 933M. But Apple also has to charge the cost of buyback (about $1.07 per share) to this quarter's earning as required by GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles). At 11 P/E, that $1.07 charge will reduce the share price by $11. To deal with this kind of situations, many companies will report two sets of earning numbers - a GAAP earning which includes the charge, and a non-GAAP earning which excludes the one-time charge. They want people to ignore the GAAP numbers. Some traders will indeed ignore that but some will not. Now, if it is going to buy back $1B each quarter for the next 10 quarters, that charge will be recurring and no longer be one time, and the hit on stock price will also accumulate. So don’t expect stock buyback will always have positive effect on stock, it may not.

Topic.Title: YHOO willing to sell at $43+...MSFT are you interested or are you going Defunct?

Message.Msg: Cash machine? Say it has $25B in cash selling off everything including all of AG and Yahoo Japan. Forget that its offshore, forget repatriation and forget the share buyback for a second. At $43x1.2B is $51.6B. Minus out that $25B in cash leaves you with $26.6B. The Yahoo core's operating income was over $850M give or take.($450M add'l was their investment income which will be gone) Why would ANYONE pay $26.6B for an asset generating only $850M? IDK about you but I'm not in the mood to wait 30yrs to breakeven on something. Let's say that MSFT DOUBLES that operating income and still its 15.5yrs just to breakeven. If I used your $20B figure it'd be even worse(37yr and 18yrs to breakeven) Sure Yahoo is cash rich but what you're asking an astronomical premium on is not. Even a 10PE only makes it worth $8.5B so $33.5B(my $25B cash figure)/1.2B=$27.91. I honestly can't get anymore generous then that.

Message.Title: PLEASE Help Me - I am Devastated! Need some advice.
Message.Msg: I had major surgery last fall and have been healing, on painkillers, etc. Well, I have made bad decisions and I am still healing from my surgery. In September 2012 I bought a considerable amount of AAPL, just before it dropped (650-700 range). I also made myself way too concentrated in AAPL. I have never done options and since I have made such terrible mistakes of not selling when it was higher, I am not going to go into options and experiment now. I do not know what to do. I am devastated. I do not want to hear people's thoughts on God, that this "doesn't matter" (it sure does matter), or criticism. I want to hear advice, please. I have enough money to live on and if I needed to go five years without working, I would be fine. I have enough to live on, so that I can wait this out if I need to. What do you think the stock price could be in one year? Do you think I am best suited to wait til this possibly goes up? I don't know what to think anymore. I hear about China Mobile, Apple TV, buy backs.. but I just don't know if I am kidding myself. Pleasee help me. I am still healing from surgery and I am not myself. I do not know what to do or what to think. Please advise. Thank you.
