Topic.Title: We just purchased 240 Iphones

Message.Msg: My company just recently got rid of our last Blackberry phone and we are all iPhone now. Only a few have the iPhone 5. People get upgraded after their existing contracts expire. Our sales department all got iPads. They have instant web and app access to the data they need. They are all much happier and it looks much slicker for the customers as well.

Message.Title: Flash dump
Message.Msg: AAPL: ‘Flash Dump’ Closes Stock at $439.88, Says ZeroHedge Email Print smaller Larger By Tiernan Ray Apple (AAPL) shares closed down $10.62, or 2.4%, at $439.88 this afternoon. ZeroHedge’s Tyler Durden points us to what appears to have back a “flash dump” in the closing moments of the market, noting a large block of $350 million worth of stock at the waning minutes of the session: Unlike traditional flash crashes where the trade is an HFT error, or a few shares traded through the entire bid or offer stack, in this case it looks like a very premeditated unloading of some 800K shares (some $350 million worth) of AAPL in the last second, with the full knowledge it was shake the market. Why anyone would want (or wait until the very last second) to do that, while covering the offsetting ES short in the pair trade, to ramp the market into the close, is anyone’s guess.

Message.Title: Margins on Phones are going to drop big time due to saturation - For AAPL and Samsung as well
Message.Msg: Smartphone cannot sustain selling for $700. Due to saturation (even grandmas have smartphones), smartphone will become a commodity product like calculator, laptop, tablet in the future. Since 70% of AAPL's income comes from Iphone, they could be in major trouble. Cost of building each unit is going up (even though they use child labor) and selling price per unit will go down. Bad scenario for P/E. So everything is great if you look in the review mirror, but unfortunately product with falling margins cannot sustain this valuation. There is still $340 Billion of valuation that depends on this product. That is just too frothy. Anything above $250 is frothy. AAPL is a show me story for 2013 because of saturation.

Topic.Title: PLEASE Help Me - I am Devastated! Need some advice.

Message.Msg: No one can be sure, but one thing I like to do is look at history,particularly relatively recent history. If you look at the lows in AAPL's share price in the latter half of 2011, they were $363 and change. It has been my observation that those lows often provide an entry point to buy. In this case, it would be a "triple bottom." Look at this from a different perspective. How did you feel about the market during 2008-2009? I'm willing to be that if you were in the market, whether via retirement accounts or otherwise, not too good. However, history has shown that if you rode out the storm in quality companies (and AAPL is one) that you made all your money back and then some. This is a similar moment--just in a single stock instead of the market as whole.

Topic.Title: Apple a bargin? No... Here is why...

Message.Msg: About a year or so ago, someone here posed the question, "Why does a stock have any value if it doesn't pay a dividend?" People piled on, the answer seemed self-evident to most, but the more I thought about it, the more confounding the question became. If a stock is not giving you back an income stream, why buy it, other than to sell it to a greater fool down the road? And this seems to work okay for investors when profits are growing wildly, but then it doesn't when that profit growth inevitably slows down (due to margin compression, unscrupulous companies that copy your technology and sell it cheaper, etc.). The only way that the company ultimately creates value for investors is by pay a reasonable income stream back to the investor to make it worth owning. What good is a company's growing cash pile if they don't share more of it? In Apple's case, people are unsure when (if ever) the next game-changing product will appear. So the fallback position is that a bigger dividend yield must be provided (which occurs either through increasing the dividend, or allowing the price of the stock to drop).

Message.Msg: You have very legit question. I have the same question too. IMHO, this is how I understand. Apple is manufacturing company dealing with hardware product to sell for consumers. Amazon has extremely high base to begin with and stock price will keep going up as long as it has going concern in keeping making money. When such merchandising co. starts to lose money or not making good money for whatever reasons, its stock price will drop like faster than meteorite. When company making hardware producst starts to run out product popularity or competition intensified or consumer interest on the product saturated, the company stock price would drop steadily until the product is reinnovated or gain selling quality. Other than that Apple may keep buring cash if stay in business with smaller profit, so the stock price. Will Apple regain its product popularity and selling quanity? I don't know, Hope to get the stock price back to the mid point near $525 at the most.

Topic.Title: Apple a bargin? No... Here is why...

Message.Msg: I only use one technical analysis outside of stat arb, and fundamentals. That single TA are horizontal lines on a log chart. Sometimes on log charts I will use trends, but only if they are rock solid (take a look at the S&P). Recently I stepped into RIM at 6.97 (sold at 17.97) because the horizontal lines said so. Look at a very very long chart of RIM. Look at where they bottomed after the long falls. Take the peak, and low and figure out what the % of the fall is. Then apply that fall to the next fall. Drum roll the price to have bought into RIM was 9ish. I waited a bit further and bought in at 6.97. Now look at MSFT, and look at their peak in 2000. Then look at their bottom around 2002. Do the math and apply that to Apple. You get a rough value of 265, where I just round up to 300. I do think that Apple will steady much like Intel has, Cisco has, Microsoft has. So you want to buy below the potential future steady of around 500. The guy who called me a dumbazz says that a good value of Apple is around 500. I actually agree there. HOWEVER, if you averaged in at 600 you are effed! I would rather average in at 300 than average in at current levels. Remember the upside to a steady of 500 is 15% with maybe a 25% pop. RIGHT... I can put my money to better use in other stocks. What people have not factored in is that 1000 USD for Apple went bye bye! The luster and halo of Apple went bye bye. And without that halo regardless of how good that company executes it will not reach 1000 USD. Ask a Microsoft shareholder. Microsoft has executed quite nicely since 2000, but the market is saying, "yawn..." REAL investors call that a value trap! And while value traps have their uses, it is not an outright purchase type of instrument. Instead you buy it for the div, and for the ability to write calls. However since one lot of Apple is 45K, writing calls is not for the faint of heart or small wallet.

Message.Title: AAPL: ‘Flash Dump’ Closes Stock at $439.88, Says ZeroHedge
Message.Msg: http://blogs.barrons.com/techtraderdaily/2013/01/25/aapl-flash-dump-closes-stock-at-439-88-says-zerohedge/?mod=yahoobarrons By Tiernan Ray Apple (AAPL) shares closed down $10.62, or 2.4%, at $439.88 this afternoon. ZeroHedge’s Tyler Durden points us to what appears to have been a “flash dump” in the closing moments of the market, noting a large block of $350 million worth of stock at the waning minutes of the session: Unlike traditional flash crashes where the trade is an HFT error, or a few shares traded through the entire bid or offer stack, in this case it looks like a very premeditated unloading of some 800K shares (some $350 million worth) of AAPL in the last second, with the full knowledge it was shake the market. Why anyone would want (or wait until the very last second) to do that, while covering the offsetting ES short in the pair trade, to ramp the market into the close, is anyone’s guess. You can see the gap down in the chart below:

Message.Msg: Read this article. He wonders why anyone would do it. Usually it is because someone threw in the towel big time. Sign of a bottom? http://blogs.barrons.com/techtraderdaily/2013/01/25/aapl-flash-dump-closes-stock-at-439-88-says-zerohedge/?mod=yahoobarrons

Topic.Title: PLEASE Help Me - I am Devastated! Need some advice.

Message.Msg: Don't Fret... Look at the fundamentals.. Apple has 1/3 of its market cap in cash and no debt. It's customers are loyal, and it has the best products. It's Price to Earnings is a rediculous 10 compared to Microsoft's 15 and Googles 22 and it's expected growth rate is higher than both google or microsoft. The market does rediculous things short term, but long term fundamentals win out. My advice would be to check apple only once a month and compare it to the S&P too. It moved way ahead of the S&P 2 years ago (almost 100%) and now is just 20% above it. I expect Apple to consistently beat the S&P from here on out. In the meantime you get 2% dividends on your shares. It probably will take years for apple to double to all time highs, but it should eventually happen.

Message.Title: You Longs listen up.
Message.Msg: A litttle more than a DECADE ago I managed to take about $20,000 and through a lot of fortunate trading turned it into $244,000. This was the great BUBBLE. When I reached this peak, I had the good sense to sell all of my crazy internet hotshots (LU, MSFT,JNPR,RFMD...). It was fantastic. I pulled out enough to pay my oldest kid's college tuition and still had a ton. Well. I bought all DUKE POWER because I was scared to death. I help it for a month or so and thought, well, the market has bottomed. It is safe to go back in the water. SO, I got interested in this Israeli tech stock and I started making money again. Well, the CEO (or was it the CFO) embezzled, cooked the books and every other nasty trick and I about $50,000 in 5 minutes the next morning. I lost all total about $140,000 that year, and was sick about it for a long time. But I never gave up on investing, I just started being a little smarter. I tried not to stick such a large percentage of my money into one company. Its called Diversity. You longs need to consider the same concept. Hang in there. AAPL is the one of the best. It is not going below $350, imho. Good Luck

Topic.Title: PLEASE Help Me - I am Devastated! Need some advice.

Topic.Title: Apple a bargin? No... Here is why...

Message.Msg: Yes I understand that earnings is much higher. But the rub with earnings is if you can keep on the trajectory. Those types of trajectories are very very hard to keep. I am arguing that while Apple is making great earnings it can't keep it up. What really made investors nervous are two things: 1) The iphone 5 is an incremental update. YES I bought it (had an iPhone 4), and am very very happy with it. However, to say that the iPhone 5 has so much of a leap ahead of say Samsung is a joke. This means the reason to keep the phone is less. Remember there are fashion and hip people who will switch phones for kicks. Remember how Nokia was numero uno for the longest time? 2) Margin compression. This is not a good thing. It is the first indication of a company that has to do more with less return. Put these two things together and the profit trajectory goes down. Look at the iPod and Mac numbers they are going down. I am not going to go as others to say that iPad sales are eating into Mac. I will say though that the initial adoption phase might be over. Mac hardware is good and as one salesman says, "these products last." That is not something you want to hear as a hardware vendor. As the profit trajectory goes down, then keeping 44.14 USD might not be that easy to maintain. Also realize that if earnings are steady state, then there is no growth, and not growth means that I cannot make money. I like Apple, but want it at a lower price.

Topic.Title: This is not the time to buy AAPL

Message.Msg: It does not "have" to go to 350. People still holding should stay calm and watch where share price settles over the next week or so. I started nibbling at $450 and will continue as (if) it continues lower. Momentum often overshoots on both the upside and the downside. Ex-dividend date is early February. AAPL is low enough now that the dividend may attract people who recognize that this fabulous brand has many incredible products and years ahead. Learn a lesson if you were not diversified. Listening to people like Cramer telling you that "everyone should own some Apple," and "if you don't own Apple, you should buy some here," when the shares were at an all time high and everyone was talking about Apple--well, that was a mistake, folks. Not paying attention to valuation is always a mistake. If you are playing the momentum game, you better know the rules. Tech tends to peak in late February as I recall. Don't sell your shares at the low for the year. Look at some charts and take some time to make up your own mind.

Topic.Title: Apple a bargin? No... Here is why...

Message.Msg: I wonder about the compression due to new products. It is not a wrong train of thought. Some traders and I have been thinking the same thing. What we wonder about though is that they have some heavy #$%$ competition these days. Case in point, macs. I could see margin compression there due to the fact that their hardware is very difficult to make (retina screen, thinner iMac, etc). However, it is there that the revenue went down. On the other hand the iPhone 5, and new iPads are not "new" devices. They are iterations of already existing devices and as such should not have put such a squeeze on margins. Thus I wonder... I do think it is margin squeeze due to cheaper products. Last year I noticed near the end of of the year stores by near me (Switzerland, and Germany) were offering about 15% to 20% discounts on Apple hardware. I never understood how they did it, but I kept buying. Last week I talked to a salesperson and he told me these are targeted actions. Thus I wonder if Apple is trying to move hardware by hitting a sweet spot that is 15 to 20% lower. That is not good IMO...

Topic.Title: Folks, if you just buy and hold for the long term, you don't have to worry about these daily fluctuations/manipulations.

Message.Msg: Another method Mr. Buffet uses is to, with very few exceptions, avoid tech stocks. While it is oft stated this is because he doesn't understand the sector, that only tells part of the story. The reality is that two of Buffet's core strategies, "buy and hold" & intrinsic value based investments, are at odds with the dynamic landscape almost by definition is the tech sector. Prudent investors will leverage different strategies in different sectors... or largely, if not completely, avoid those sectors that do not typically align with their investment strategies.

Give it another week and you'll see.

Topic.Title: Another Horrible Weekend ahead, if you are like me and long.... . The loses Ive taken with this are insane..... Im down over

Message.Msg: There are a couple of ways to make money when you buy a stock: 1) Invest in a company that is growing profits quickly, and then sell somewhere down the line to a greater fool; or 2) Collect a nice, predictable dividend. The trickiest one is the first, as a profits can’t grow fast forever (due to margin compression, competitors who copy your technology and sell it cheaper, the law of large numbers, etc.) So the game, I suppose, is to try and guess at what point a company is changing from #1 (where you can still sell to greater fools) to #2 (which requires a high dividend yield, accomplished either by raising the dividend or allowing the price of the stock to fall). Right now it would appear Apple is in no man’s land, as investors are unsure whether they will make money using the first approach above, or if the stock is turning more into a dividend stock, whereby you must provide an attractive dividend yield to attract more investors. The question you must ask yourself is whether you think Apple’s profits can continue the incredible growth of the past, or if the stock price will have to fall more to entice dividend investors. I came to the conclusion that we are witnessing Apple’s slow, agonizing transition from a growth company, and sold after earnings were released. I’d held this stock since 2006, so it wasn’t an easy decision (yes, I made a nice profit, but I still missed out on much higher prices in the fall, which is painful). There are things the company could have done the past few months to at least staunch the bleeding (increase buy-backs, split the shares, increase the dividend), but they chose not to. And when they didn’t even throw investors a bone on this latest earnings call, I personally lost faith and decided to take my profit. I still love the company and its products, but a stock is different from the company. Man, I miss Steve Jobs...

Message.Msg: You should NEVER gamble money you can't afford to lose on stocks. The market can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent. I do not know how low AAPL will drop, I'm holding at an 8% loss currently and plan to hold this until I have a 20% gain (which I'm hoping will be by September). This is called "catching a falling knife". You and I both just did it. It is very risky to do in the short-term. I bought some AAPL @ $497/share before they announced earnings, then when the stock dropped 10% I bought more. I'm comfortable holding this stock through the volatility, but it sounds like you are not. Just undo your trade (i.e. sell for a small loss) and realize you made a big mistake, and stay away from stocks until you understand well that whatever money you put in you could lose it all. This stock could continue dropping to $400/share, even lower. Nobody knows. Sure, the valuation is really good, but if more people are selling than buying it will keep dropping.

Message.Title: Stop Loss
Message.Msg: For all of you who see these sad stories of people losing money by the fists full, always use a stop. I can say this from experience. I've had some losses where I wanted to jump off a building. The second after you push the buy button, decide how much you are willing to lose before you sell and put in a market stop. This will take all of the emotion out of the trade. If you get stopped out and the stock soars past where you sold, so be it. You live another day to try again. A lot of money moved out of this stock but it will come back in. If you rode this down big, the pain is almost over and you are still alive. Nobody will leave this planet with their money. Enjoy life while you have it. Life is not about money. Have a glass of wine and enjoy the weekend.

Topic.Title: need serious advise

Message.Msg: At $460 I think you will be fine given it doesn't sound like you need the money short term, you are just concerned about losing it. im_long_appl gave you some good advice regarding potentially using a stop loss and that is something to keep in mind not just with your current AAPL holdings, but all your future equity investments. Just keep in mind that if you set them too tightly, they can work against you... especially in situations like this where you bought when a stock was still in a down trend. Speaking of which, resist any urge you may have to cost average down until the stock becomes stable and begins to recover. Aside from that... the cliches are cliches because they are generally accurate. Don't try to catch a falling knife. Don't invest more than you are prepared to lose. And diversify your portfolio across individual stocks, sectors, and other investment vehicles. On the plus side, it's great to see you starting your investment career at such a young age. You're obviously a smart guy or you wouldn't be a grad student. Just follow the above rules, especially as you are still learning about investing, and I am sure you will do very well!

Topic.Title: 89% pepole in stock market end up lost most of their money, 14 years we not know anbody made it on this MB

Message.Msg: Not true! You are way off base. Anyone can make money in the market. You just have to acknowledge the risk reward ratio and know your style of tradings. A conservative investor can make 10% a year by the old fashion way: diversify. Holding high paying dividend stocks like utilities, and some grow stocks combinations. No, this will not make you rich overnight, but you won't lose your shirt either. My style is I don't buy junk, penny, and high flying stocks. Everyone is different, you must know yourselves. Pay attention to the news, not hyped. Do the homework on the stocks you own. I read about AAPL rate of grow slowing down, and the warnings weeks ago, and I wasn't even looking for it. Someone told me long ago, that if I lose sleep at night worrying about my stocks, it's time to sell down to the level I can be comfortable with. I'm sure AAPL will make a come back, but how long will it be? and at what price?

Topic.Title: Apple is on it's way to transitioning from a growth play to a value play

Message.Msg: I reluctantly came to the same conclusion the past couple of weeks. The earnings call was the final nail in the coffin for me, it's like current management just has no clue as to how they can pump up the stock price. Although I'm mad at myself for not selling sooner, I'd held since 2006 ($60/share), so I console myself with my overall return (it always sucks to leave money on the table, though). Investors who held Microsoft, Dell, CIsco, Intel, back in the day all had to go through this transition. It's difficult to know (and accept) when this transition is actually happening, perhaps one of the most difficult things for a stock investor to understand.

Message.Title: any margin doomsayer, here is the news for you
Message.Msg: Apple is at the top of the food-chain in any of its five major products: iPhone, iPad, iMac, MacBook and iTune. While it cannot maintain the high profit margin, it can drop the price to cannibalize the products on the lower part of the food chain. The result is revenue grows faster than profit. The challenge is to meet the demand, not that there is not enough demand. The market is over-reacting. There are plenty of guys who has made a lot of money on this stock. It is time to switch hands.

Topic.Title: iPhone 4 & 5 constrained last quarter...this came from seeking alpha earnings transcript. What happens when NOT constrained? lmao.

Message.Msg: quarter. We did have significant shortages due to robust demand on both iPad mini and both models of the iMac that persisted the entire quarter. And we are still short of both of those today as the matter of fact. Additionally, supply of iPhone 5 which short to demand until late in the quarter and iPhone 4 was short for the entire quarter, we believe that we can achieve a supply demand balance on iPad mini during this quarter and on iPhone 4 during this quarter. On iMac, we are confident that we are going to significantly increase the supply, but the demand here is very strong and we are not certain that we will achieve a supply demand balance during the quarter.

Message.Title: something good will come out of this:
Message.Msg: Call me an eternal optimist, but I am kind of glad we had the devastation we had this week. I, like alot of people on here own aapl at might higher levels and kept averaging down. We saw NFLX move 70% in two days, and every other high P/E stock has been off to the races. This reminds me very much of 99. Apple is still a rock solid company and I have no doubt it will recover, but like alot of people on here, I am getting tired of COOK and completely fed up with this CFO, Oppenheimer. I think alot of the stock drop was due to their arrogance on the call and not appeasing the analysts. They were cocky and evasive with their answers. The handling of the stock has been a disgrace. Cook just kept saying is " all we care about is making products that people not just like, but love" over and over. This is not how you address Wall St Analysts. Their handling of the stock with no split, div boost, or buyback acceleration has been a disgrace. At this point, the war drums are starting to beat. Something good will happen. These guys will wake up from all the complaints they are receiving, or key people there will leave. Bottom line, Apple is not a broken stock, just a victim of their own success and arrogance. Time will fix this. You just need to be patient. I suggest selling covered weekly calls for the time being until a catalyst shows up. Just my two cents.

Topic.Title: iPhone 4 & 5 constrained last quarter...this came from seeking alpha earnings transcript. What happens when NOT constrained? lmao.

Message.Msg: Today we have 24 carriers on LTE around the world for iPHone 5. Those are in countries like the US, Korea, UK, Germany, Canada, Japan and Australia and a few others. Next week, we are adding 36 more carriers for LTE support. And these carriers will be in countries that were currently not supporting LTE, so the LTE coverage now as of next week in Italy, Denmark, Finland, Switzerland, Philippines, also several Middle Eastern countries. And so if you look at the total of all of these and the incremental subscribers that are in those countries, that’s over 300 million.

Topic.Title: need serious advise

Message.Msg: You are asking a question which has no answer. Why do you think that fundamentals, p/e and etc can control the price of a stock? Sure, When things are calm, yes you can actually see the "fair value" but when the boat is rocking hard, no one knows. your analysis can be right but what good will it do when market disagree with you? I have been in the market 15+yrs... APPL is going down because its where the people think it is fair at. You see, every tick, there has to be an agreement on price between a buyer and a seller but disagreement on the value. So the price of aapl is fair for now. do you understand? If you have bought in without margin, aapl needs to goto 0 for you to lose everything. so you will not lose everything if you stay in. however, the direction, I do not know. all I see is they trend is down and it looks bad..closing 2days near the low is not what you want to see if you are long. Last, when you enter a trade, please note that only thing you can control is your risk. you CAN NOT control where the price will go. so please! manage your risk. determine the amount of your risk. you are buying aapl at 460 and like to test your theory on valuation? good! then go ahead by putting your money on the line. but know this, your exit plan needs to be planned ahead of clicking on BUY on your brokerage account. So In your case, maybe risking 30% which is at 322, set it as your stop loss point. Sure, it can gap down below your stop point but at least it gives you an idea of what is on the line. I explain this to you because you said that you were a student. hope this can help you a little. Good luck.

Message.Title: Apple's global ARM score of 10
Message.Msg: Apple is the lowest ranked stock among the marquee technology firms in the United States based on the change in analyst sentiment, or Analysts Revision Model (ARM), according to StarMine. Apple's global ARM score of 10 is well below Google Inc's 34 and Microsoft Corp's 19 out of a possible 100. Nokia and Samsung have scores of 82 and 89, respectively. Research in Motion Ltd has a perfect score of 100, according to the model, which measures analysts' revision of key indicators such as earnings and revenue estimates and changes to their ratings.

Topic.Title: Lets Look at some facts.. And please only rational people respond .. Short or long .. But bashers please take a coffee brake

Message.Msg: 10-14% drop from $44 not a flat 10-14 dollar drop. The analysts will start revising down once 2nd quarter hits. Most analysts need to be hit in the face before they admit they are wrong. The more I crunch the numbers the more I think $11 is the top of the range with $10.50 a bottom. The long term issues become what new products will apple release and can they capitalize on their ecosystem. Jobs screwed up by not going with a different variety of products and price points sooner. He could have ended the fight with Samsung before it even began and have a huge share of the global market. Of course the positive in all this is margin compression is built in for future quarters. Not that they will expand again, but it was inevitable and one less thing for analysts to worry about if Apple does continue to grow revenue. Good luck with your investment.

Topic.Title: PLEASE Help Me - I am Devastated! Need some advice.

Message.Msg: First, realize that the market is smarter than you or anyone else here. The fact is that AAPL will either go up or down, and no one knows for sure (especially not technical analysts, who are extremely delusional). Second, if you want to limit the range of anticipated results, buy both a total maket index fund & total bond fund in an allocation appropriate for your risk tolerance and time horizon. Then occassionally rebalance to your target allocation. Finally, once you've done the second step above, sleep well at night knowing you'll not ever have to eat Alpo (and you'll beat approx 90% of professional money managers over the long haul).

Message.Title: Dumping over 2M shares at mkt close to make sure closing under $440
Message.Msg: I was watching how option related trading of AAPL the last 5 minutes before market close today. It was trading around $444 at 3:55pm ET. Over 2M shares were dumped in the last 5 minutes to make sure to close under $440. So, it went to as low as $435 in that period. If we look at the option trading of AAPL, there were over 1M contracts (or 100M shares of AAPL stock) CALL/PUT in all strke prices on this month and next month. Yes, the option trading is extremely active in AAPL. When its stock price is closed under $440, all the $440 CALL or higher strike price will be $0 and all of $440 PUT or higher strike price will be much higher price. If I want to dump 2M shares of AAPL, I will buy the PUT option and sell $440 CALL option before dumping my shares. Then I may lose money on the stock but I made money from the option. 2M shares are only 20K contracts. Remember, I can do it in all srike price in CALL and PUT. If I did 100K contracts, then I made more money from option than losing money in stock. Great strategy.

Message.Title: Since everyone else is telling their AAPL story, I may as well too.......
Message.Msg: I originally bought AAPL on October 13, 2008 @ $104 / share. I've sold at $700, $612, and $503, but still have a lot left. The shares I do have are IRA / 401(k). I'm 37 and would anticipate working another 30 years. If my horizon is 30 years, is there any reason I should sell? My biggest gripe is that I keep watching AAPL drop while the other stocks I watch (HAL, CVX, SODA, EBAY, MMM, etc.) keep going up. My general consensus is that AAPL fundamentals are rock solid, but that AAPL is its own worst enemy right now. Back in the Steve days, guidance would be provided and 90 days later the guidance would be doubled. AAPL conditioned the market (like Pavlov) to expect this beat every 90 days. Now, they are just meeting guidance. However, they are still growing. I can honestly also say that my participation on this board is purely entertainment but I do value the logical responses. If you had $100k lying around that you weren't going to need for 30 years, what would you do? Thanks to all on this board for entertaining me! I honestly appreciate it! : - ) Disclosure - no idea, used to be strong buy, now not sure.

Topic.Title: This Is What I Dont Understand..

Message.Msg: I don't believe that people have an issue with Apple making huge profits. The problem is most people initially fell for the Apple hype with regards to being on the cutting edge of technology, and at one point in time they were. Until Steve Jobs died. Unfortunately, Tim Cook is not Steve Jobs and now the cat is out of the bag that products such as the new iPhone 5 isn't that cutting edge after all besides a decent exterior. However, once you get past all of the hype, one realize the same can be achieved using cost effective (Android device) for the fraction of the price. Sure, in the beginning Android devices were plagued with many operational issues but that was then, this is now. We are now living in a value driven economy. No longer are most of us mesmerized by just fancy bells, whistles, fancy packaging and hype. We want stuff that's affordable, works well and of course, "OPENED SOURCE", not this Apple "CLOSED SOURCE" like iTunes.

Message.Title: Is this old news or something new?
Message.Msg: Earlier today there was a report in from iLounge talking about the supposed new iPhone 5S and iPad 5. Alongside the rumors earlier, some new information has come to light from “another trusted source,” who “offered a handful of additional details.” So let’s just dive right in, shall we. According to the report, the iPhone 5S is “months away” from mass production, and will sport a 13MP Sony made camera on a back – a pretty big jump from the current 8MP camera on the iPhone 5. As is expected, the source also said that the iPhone 5S would be getting a newer, faster processor, and currently the prototype names are N51 and N53. July is what the release date is said to be. Not too much on the iPad 5, other than the codename is J72, and still is looking like an October release, per the first report. The iPad mini 2nd generation, however, codenamed J85, is currently planned for October as well, but is said to be receiving a Retina display. This would make sense to give the tablet a new display, as that was one of the only complaints when the device was released. The “look and feel” of the device, however, is said to just be the same as before. All of this information is an update to what was said earlier, which included the iPad 5 being much thinner and taking design cues from the iPad mini.

Topic.Title: A stock usually bottoms when

Message.Msg: I could see buying some now, but as for a bottom until it becomes attractive to income investors I wouldnt feel confident about a bottom. I think around a 3% dividend (350ish) it would find support. Not saying it wont hit a bottom before then, but even at this price put options are about 15% more expensive than call options which tells me it still has room to run on the downside. Assuming they announce the dividend increase in March like they announced the dividend last year a buy at the end of Feb, start of March would seem logical as well. Sure if it's something ridiculous like a 10% increase it wont impact the stock at all, but if they care about shareholders at all and bump it up 25% it could give it a nice bump. Good luck.

Message.Title: Did a crazy option trade late in the day and oddly enough it might payoff on Monday (or not!)
Message.Msg: Decided just before 4 PM to SELL 10 of the 440 Weekly Puts that were going to expire in about 3 minutes today. The stock was trading around 443 at that time and I wanted to get my cash position to a nice round number so I sold them for a mere .02 (20 bucks minus commission got me about 12 bucks which is all I wanted to get my cash position to a nice round number). I know it sounds crazy but I thought it would be a safe trade with 3 minutes left in the day! So of course, what happens? AAPL plummets over 3 bucks in the last 10 seconds of the day (!!!) and I frantically try to close the position and miss buying back the options by 1 second! So now they are ITM and I will suddenly be the owner of 1000 shares of AAPL on Monday at 440.00 (my cash position isn't that large so I will be margined quite a bit of course!). The odd thing is there is a slight chance that the options won't be assigned despite being ITM because some options owners elect NOT to exercise them because the AH price is very close to 440 (it actually closed at 441.00 at 8 pm!). So here is the dilemma. My feeling is that 2 things might happen- I get assigned and the stock plummets on Monday to 420 and I lose 20K immediately (on paper of course) or I don't get assigned even though I SHOULD and then I will see AAPL rebound dramatically on Monday to 460+ and I will have missed out on the best opportunity in a long time. We shall see if I get lucky or not.

Topic.Title: PLEASE Help Me - I am Devastated! Need some advice.

Message.Msg: Stocks is a dirty business, manipulated in several ways by professionals with huge cash to use against small embarassed investors, so let me say first of all that a person in your condition should get out from it immediately, and concentrate on his own health. The more if you may survive 5 years without working and gambling. Second, NO ONE in this world knows what will happen in a week: do you really think it's possible to tell you where AAPL will be in a year ??? Then you may believe anything. Third: since I've been trading with options for 7 years, I can tell you just this: be very very careful with options. Options are much more complicated than stocks, since you must be right not only with regard to the stock direction, but also to time decay and crazy volatility effects. AAPL options are very expensive, normally it's better to write them rather than buying them, anyway you must know very well what you are doing. Again, my sincere suggestion is to take care of you, your family and your interests. Enjoy your time.

Topic.Title: I lost a lot of money but sold at 450 --- Need some advice!

Message.Msg: I don't think you need a margin account to trade options. But you do need to sign up for option trading. A margin account is like a double edged sword. One must use margin account very carefully. From your messages, I would caution you to use margin (i.e., leverage) very carefully. You talked about charting. Please remember most charts are lagging tools. They fail at inflection points. Do the fundamental analysis first. BTW, most charts today would show you stocks are in over-bought zones. If Apple Inc. comes up with Apple TV today and/or it has decided to go after the corporate PC users because those users can link their iPhones to their corporate systems, Apple stocks will jump up if they could prove the improvement of productivity.

Message.Title: AAPL Here we go !
Message.Msg: January 25, 2013 | 39 commentsby: Stephen Faulkner | about: AAPL, includes: GOOG Disclosure: I have no positions in any stocks mentioned, but may initiate a long position in AAPL over the next 72 hours. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article. (More...) I'll start off by clearly stating that I am no Apple (AAPL) fan. I have never in my life owned an Apple product, and I may never own an Apple product. I dislike the company, the culture, and the whole atmosphere around "Apple." I'm a Microsoft (MSFT) fan. I'm a Google (GOOG) fan. I'm an Intel- (INTC) loving, PC-loving, Apple-hating monster in the eyes of those loyal to what is seemingly America's number one loved company. The Past That being said, my dislike of the company and products has cost me dearly. Despite recognizing the importance of the MP3 player and centering a large project around a portable MP3 player while in college in 1998, I chose to not invest in the one company that would take such a concept and revolutionize the music industry forever. Despite recognizing the importance and impending popularity of the smartphone when Apple introduced the iPhone, I chose not to invest in the one company that would take this concept and revolutionize the fledgling smartphone industry. The writing was on the wall for these two technologies and the company that would run miles ahead in the race. Apple grabbed them, held them high, and sprinted ahead of the pack in elegant form and with near perfect execution. I cringe every day I look at Apple's share price, not because of the sharp declines since September, but because I should have known better back in 2004.

Message.Title: Teenage kids are moving away from iPhone to Samsung Galaxy s III
Message.Msg: I have first hand experience of Verizon and AT&T employees leaving iPhone for the Samsung S3. I would ask why you would want to leave the iTunes (music/video) ecosystem....I would get a laugh and the next comment was I would keep the iPhone and use it as an iPod. WoW, crazy answer....but the reality is younger people are not as dedicated or loyal toward Apple products. When I bought in on Apple shares (at $128) my influence was the local kids giving rave reviews on the iPhone...now they are down on Apple because they don't see future products coming out (A Plan) that would keep them loyal. This has been painful for Longs and Apple guidance is at a minimum, with management standing around with hands in their pockets. They should send a survey out to they're existing and past customers to opine on the current situation. Apple silence strategy may have worked for Steve Job (visionary), but the latest management/Board has no clue what to do if any on providing reassurance for existing or future Apple investors. I feel better now...my 1 cent opinion.

Topic.Title: PLEASE Help Me - I am Devastated! Need some advice.

Message.Msg: The sad part is that stocks are not for everyone and the general rule of playing only with money you can afford to loose often gets lost in the world of greed. Never purchase stocks that are THE trend of the moment. I got into Apple in 2005 at around 37$ and sold out between $610 and $640. Yes, I made good money but we must remember that at that time the stock was ranking up the numbers each day like crazy and when it hit $700 I remember some of my friends telling me how stupid I was to have sold so early. The thing is, timing the lows and tops is impossible, but playing the stocks that are too much in the spotlight is a sure way to fail. People remember the solar panel stocks, when LDK was $50, people were saying it was going to go to 100 or 200, its now what, less than $2 today. Same for First Solar, we all remember that one and the spotlight it had. Went from less than $50 to over $300 in no time and people were talking of $500 as the next step. Its now about $30. How many people lost their savings on these stocks even when the so called analysts were preaching miracles for them. Don't get fooled. Find stocks that are not too popular so far, stay out of the stocks that seem too grow with no end in sight. I recently sold DDD, got in late 2011 at a price in the mid teens and kept it until it touched about $50, then started to sell in phases until it reached $60 and I bailed out. Its now almost $70 and recently touched $72. But at a price/earning of over 100, this is not serious anymore, even if some analyst say this stock is going to $100 and then higher, good luck to them. I prefer to follow Buffet's 2 rules (don't loose money and don't forget about the first rule). And always, always, always use only a portion of your money on any single stock, even if the urge to pour in a ton of money on that miracle stock is burning you. Even the best horse can stumble while running for no apparent reason and in the end he will not win the race. Good luck to all.

Message.Title: Ironic that AAPL has to rely on Asia to show growth
Message.Msg: Now that the US market is saturated with smartphones, AAPL needs to rely on China to show growth. Mind you, AAPL is catering to the middle and upper class echelon in Asia and China. These folks are butt loaded thanks to all the outsourcing of US corporation jobs to China which includes AAPL. I'm talking about the plant owners, real estate developers, managers etc whose families are enriched by greedy US corporation. Think about that. Now AAPL investors need Asia and especially China middle class folks to buy Iphones and Ipads so AAPL can grow profits. I am not bashing the Chinese as I am Chinese myself. Just wanted to throw out there. Wouldn't it be nice if the jobs in China were brought back to the US so the US folks here could afford an Iphone and further drive AAPL growth? What are your thoughts? Message.Title: Long Term Damage
Message.Msg: I have been bullish on AAPL to this point, but I have a lot of legit concerns long-term. My biggest concern is that the brand is going to suffer permanent damage due to this massive decline. Most of the people that buy Apple products don't pay attention to the market or even care. However, any person that watches the news or financial channels, or reads financial information is going to be inundated with bad news regarding Apple. At some point this will feed into people's subconscious and they will think Apple makes a bad product just based on the information they receive. That problem is multiplied even more by the fact that the man who drove the companies growth was one of the most innovative people of our time. He was replaced by an inept CEO that does not have the same allure. Jobs was able to play Wall Street, snub tech shows, wear terrible clothes, act like a hippie, and sandbag guidance because of his track record. Cook on the other hand has built a reputation as someone that constantly misses on earnings, and has little innovation. If this company is to make a real turn around it is going to need a serious change of attitude. Cook needs to defend the share price. Rather than saying "don't bet against apple" he should say "I am betting on Apple." He should increase dividend, not to scare the shorts, but to reward investors that have been pounded by his ineptitude. He should buy innovative companies that fit into the Apple Eco system. Most importantly, he needs to be more open minded. If a larger screen is what the people want, give it to them. If you need to sell a cheaper phone to broaden the users, do it. Lastly, if you have things in the pipeline that are innovative build them up publicly like Jobs did. Give people a reason to stick with both the stock and the product.

Topic.Title: PLEASE Help Me - I am Devastated! Need some advice.

Message.Msg: Many times the best thing to do is nothing, especially for investors (as opposed to traders). Also, don't forget you will be getting a dividend, likely to increase, while you're waiting which eventually should just be icing on the cake when the stock price returns. Annually, this should be worth at least $12 to $15 per share per year. Treat the stock as a capital investment to pay off eventually in the longer term (or at least break even) and treat the dividend as interest / income which can either be reinvested or kept for any purpose you desire. Basically, there is nothing fundamentally wrong with APPLE as a business/company so all the selling is mostly about a natural transition from a blow-your-socks-off growth company to a larger, established value company (good, solid revenue streams but just not growing as fast anymore). There is consequently a natural rotation in the type of investor interested in this type of company and a lot of questions concerning exactly how this will transpire. Lots of investor anxiety right now but clearly APPLE has huge resources and capabilities to resolve these questions.

Topic.Title: Did a crazy option trade late in the day and oddly enough it might payoff on Monday (or not!)

Message.Msg: You do go by the closing price at 4 PM but there are times that after hours events can create a chaotic situation for options before they close out on Saturday (especially in Biotech or buyout situations). With the weeklies the time frame is earlier though- they close on Friday. I will let you know what happens on Monday for sure. Ameritrade says that ITM from 1 to 4 cents it is up to the owner of the option to exercise the option but at 5 cents or more Ameritrade makes an automatic assignment so it would appear that they will be assigned but Ameritrade probably won't be that interested in having me buy shares from them for 440 if they already see it at 441 today at 8 pm. Interested to see how this plays out. And yes. massive manipulation DOES occur sometimes (especially with options that expire at 4:15 PM (like VXX options)).

Topic.Title: NOBODY TALKES ABOUT PUT PROTECTION????

Message.Msg: Good for you! on buying protection. I have the same issue with put protection but it sure helps in situations like this one. I looked at buying protection but didn't. (decided to place ITM calls instead and was going to use part of the proceeds from that to buy puts but decided against it (a mistake indeed). I think the way buy-puts are supposed to work is that you are supposed to buy them a few months out where there is next to no time decay. Then, when the intrinsic value rises as the stock falls you close them out with little or no time decay involved and if the stock jumps up instead of down, you need to close them out immediately before there can be much of a loss.

Topic.Title: Did a crazy option trade late in the day and oddly enough it might payoff on Monday (or not!)

Message.Msg: Just curious, did you do this on margins or do you have the cash to cover the assigned price. When I 1st did option trades on AAPL, I miscalculated the option assigned price. I shorted 7 puts @ 505 PUTS thinking I would be put at 35,350. I saw my margins buying power drop significantly. I then realized my actual assigned price was 353,500. Decided to hold on. Come Friday expiration, the stock drops close to the 505 strike price. I waited 10 minutes to closing as it touched 505.38 and panicked and decided to close out. Too make a long story short, my PC glitched up and I put a market order in and got a bad price. With 2 minutes left, the price jumped to 509+. Instead of taking profits, I suffer a 300 loss. Oh well. This was back on Dec 14.

Topic.Title: I need serious help... please help..... I'm truthfully speaking here so I please be kind.

Message.Msg: COOFEBOOK1 I cannot tell you when AAPL will bottom or go back up. AAPL is still a great company and will have buyers coming in to take positions because it both pays a dividend and is a company that produces multiple products. I suspect that it will fill a gap up in the price at $405 to $409 and at that point it will start to draw more buyers. Look at selling JAN 2015 put option between $250 and $350. You would be paid a premium and can buy the option back at a much lower price then what you sold it for. I never buy call or put options as 95% of call and put option buyers will lose money. Search the term option pain. Sell offs like this start with the big money men running the price of a stock up so they can sell tons of call options. To profit they have to create some sort of perceived problem that will drive the stock price down and all call options so they can buy those options back for next to nothing. Option pain is a calculated price at which 95% of call and put option buyers will lose money. When the stock price bottoms out the very same big money men sell put options and the drive the price of the stock back up and all the put options they sold become worth much less, and once again they buy those options back at a discount. Then the game is set for another go around. I follow this manipulation and when the price of a stock is below its option pain price; i sell puts, and when the stock price moves up to or over the option pain price; I will buy the put options back for less. I look to capture 20% to 50% of the premium. I have to do research for each trade; but it is well worth the time. I have never lost money by using my put option strategy. I have lost money buying stocks or call options. The stocks that I screen for must pay at least a 3% dividend. I want to use stocks that investors want to purchase when the price drops and the dividend goes up. XQ

Message.Title: What is going to happen to AAPL from now (Facts)
Message.Msg: So, AAPL lost %30 of its peak value before the report and an extra %12 after that. The initial attack was from the hedge funds.They kept taking out their money (those share that they bought at much lower prices) to close the year end accounts, while still making %100 or %200 money. By cashing their funds out of AAPL they were also able to pump the price done to load it again (which they were able to do). On the other hand, AAPL was highly expected to come of with slightly better results to end the fight and let the stock breath. That did not happen, stock got shocked and headed down by another %12. Bottom-line, today hedge funds reached their main goads: 1- Lowering AAPL's market cap below $415b to make it stand on the second stage after EXXON. 2- Pushing it lower than its 52 week $443 3- Lowering its P/E to one digit 9.99. After achieving these goals, I believe apple has already reached to its main resistance level which from the charts is $425. I think AAPL board are wise enough (at least I hope) to do some think such as buy-back, or higher dividend, or even one big news like china-mobile contract which can potentially move the stock higher. Again, I believe all funds already have achieved their goals so it should be a good entry for those how want to be short or long.

Message.Title: Yes it is cheap on valuation...But...
Message.Msg: Apple is no doubt cheap by any rational measure of valuation....BUT, it still is just a gadget maker at this point in time and those gadgets are fast becoming a commodity. Clearly, these gadgets have revolutionized the world in many respects but now that reality is changing into the recognition that they merely sell the same "stuff" as everyone else. They have become a victim of their own success. What else could totally derail the silicon valley wonders of the world that no one ever seems to consider....Anybody ever think that a concentration of the brainpower of these major tech companies are in the Bay area- earthquake country. What if some major catastrophic event occured...(think Japan earthquake)...and took down alot of the intellectual property of the great innovators concentrated in the Bay area of California...merely food for thought that is never spoken about. Maybe it is not as "cheap" as it seems.

Topic.Title: What is going to happen to AAPL from now (Facts)

Message.Msg: Apple is a very good company with excellent products but the fact is that the stock is going much lower. I am neither long nor short. I just don't like shorting but I am confident that this stock is going much lower. The main reason is the market cap.. Imagine a 400 billion dollar company selling phones and tablets. All those ecosystem blah blah does not matter much...The huge margins and the volume of units had helped them until now but with both these decreasing, the p/e is bound to go up rapidly with any miss. The market is simply preparing for it before hand. Please Please do not consider this as a long term investment. It might have an occassional bounce but the direction is downward. The market cap is its main enemy. Imagine generating 50Billion dollars every quarter to maintain a p/e of 10. That is almost the size of Facebook every quarter. How long will it go and that too with more and more competitiors in the market.

Message.Title: Rotten Apples make good Fertilizer w Cash FWD PE of Just 6.06x
Message.Msg: Apple ended Q1 2013 with $137.112 billion in cash & investments (around $43 billion of which is held in the United States), and based on 947,217,000 diluted shares outstanding, the company holds $144.75 per share in cash & investments. Based on Apple's closing price of $450.50 on January 24, 32.13% of Apple's market capitalization is in cash. In our view, this is unwarranted. Apple's cash balance now accounts for almost a third of the company's market value, and if it were to be excluded, Apple's trailing P/E would fall to 6.93, and its forward multiple would fall to just 6.06x. Are Apple's days of easy growth behind it? Perhaps they are. But with a trailing multiple approaching single digits, and forward multiples already there, Apple's shares are priced at multiples that suggest the company will never grow again. While Apple's Q2 guidance suggests that growth will slow in the quarter, Apple's forecasts for both operating expenses and capital expenditures imply the company is preparing for growth in the remainder of 2013, and we think it is unwise to jump to conclusions about the second half of the year based on one quarter of guidance. Apple's multiples are hardly stretched, and with a dividend yield of 2.35%, Apple's shares are pricing in a bleak future, something we believe is unwarranted. From Seeking Alpha
